The developers of this game are frustrating people - They have this amazing game concept but they refuse to buckle down and finish their games. Instead, they move on to some nonsense project and discontinue support for what they originally had going, something a lot of people cared about. Survival Ascended is a graphics mod being marketed as a full game, if you want to go back to how things were - you cannot. They took the official servers offline and none of the privates run with original rules.

If you don't care about getting 100+ wood from punching a tree and leveling up to lvl 50 in ten minutes, then I guess there's still a game left here. What I loved about this product is seemingly gone and what I disliked has been empowered. 

Doesn't help that the developers censor anyone who gives negative feedback on the game from public channels. Goes to show you their business model revolves around constantly moving on and on without putting the proper work into polishing their products. It's a shame, they have talent, they don't need to act like grifters

Around 1800 hours with my PS4 game-time. We started off in PvP servers for about a week but it was too difficult. We moved on to PvE and the rest is history. The game is borderline addicting, you can definitely miss out on life while getting into ARK. From waking up at 3 am to feed baby dinos, to taming thezis with berries for 12 hours, this game will have you missing out on your graduation, wedding, childs birthday party and so on. Play with caution.

This game is a really cool concept, but the game itself is broken.

Main problems:

Major performance issues to the point where the quality of your PC almost doesn't matter.

Server Lag (obviously it is very difficult to have non-laggy servers in an open world game like this one, but it is worse than any other game of this genre that I have seen).

Countless random bugs such as with hit registration, getting stuck in parts of the map, getting stuck in dinos, structures not snapping correctly or even just not building at all (might be linked to lag), and crashing.

PvP is unplayable. Coming from not only the issues above but also the horrendous balancing of the game from a PvP standpoint. Large groups that have been established for a long time have total control of servers and have gear that is impossible to compete with as a solo player or small group starting out. This is mainly a problem on official servers but the gear part is definitely a factor on unofficial/community ones as well. Other balancing issues include items in the game such as the bola, a projectile that when hit on an enemy player, makes them unable to move for 30 seconds. Other more minor concepts such as the existence of caging worsen the PvP experience but overall these are the primary things that make PvP as unplayable as it is.

I wouldn't count on any of these issues being fixed, at least any time remotely soon. The developers of this game have a "quantity over quality" mindset, and instead of fixing the existing game, choose to just release and cram more content into the game.

Despite all this I think this can be a very fun PvE game, especially with friends. It has what is in my opinion a very cool story and a fun progression route that gives you a very unique experience when compared to any other open world survival out there.

Before anything, I want to say that my review is not a part of reviewbombing this game because of ASA, accusations about Snail Games' malicious practices or any other drama related to the UE5 remake, but rather an honest, hopefully unbiased rewiev of the game in its current state coming from a person that loved and played it since 2017.

Oh ARK, what could you've been if it wasn't for some incompetent decisions made by original creators? What if Wildcard just waited a bit more with their release to avoid that $40 million lawsuit?

The game started as a simple survival with dinosaurs, where you begin with primitive tools, armor and structures, then advance and with time obtain better and better technology to prevail. Most things weren't overshadowed or useless, because worse gear would allow you to obtain some things very early in the game, while the better one was locked behind a huge amount of grind in mid- to late-game.
Then the devs started adding the story, tek, DLCs, new dinos etc. and I'm cool with that. ARK had potential to become the ultimate survival sandbox experience with all that wacky stuff that was being added. Game was still pretty balanced, became a bit easier and forgiving in some parts, it has become very customizable in terms of difficulty, and the player was given more options and toys to play around with.

What I'm not cool with is how they threw all the balance they had through the window with the release of Extinction and each subsequent DLC, adding more overpowered tools and tames that would make vanilla creatures borderline useless and annoy players on PVP servers once transfers were turned on. It became the definition of pay to win.

The game is also riddled with bugs since the day of release. Dinos and lootbags spawning/falling out of bounds, softlocks, random crashses, rocks and trees spawning inside player's base despite turning it off in settings and other specific stuff that even checking file compatibility via Steam or redownloading wouldn't fix. I've played around with godmode, destroyed one terminal and it didn't spawn back even after downloading the game again. It's like they're uploading your saved world to steam cloud but instead of dinos, structures etc. they upload the base world with the tweaks you did to it.

Most features remain unstable/unfinished, like Primitive+ DLC and procedurally generated worlds. Re-fertilizer still doesn't work and taming rates for some creatures aren't balanced properly despite them being in the game for as long as 5 years.

There's a lot of optimization issues, however with all the games made on Unreal Engine that I've played, I think it might be the issue with engine itself or just my PC having 1050ti and being really old.

The worst part being, none of those issues will ever be adressed, because devs moved on to work on ARK: Survival Ascended and ARK II and because of Snail Games' greedy tactics.

ARK has creative creature designs, a fun premise and gameplay, especially with DLC creatures, looks pretty and you can still rent servers to play with friends if you want, I can't find any other positive aspect of this game.

As of writing, the game slowly loses interest. Less and less people play it. Modders and youtubers have moved on, so now workshop is spammed with Chinese potential IP grabbers, while normal mods are left discontinued in the back of workshop. This is the sad end of a game that had incredible potential but instead became a mediocre, unoptimized mess.

Wow what a game, I truly enjoy coming home after a long day of work to start Ark and try to push through the most upsetting set of game mechanics ever to have graced steam. You and your friends will enjoy hours of grinding and resource gather to only watch it all go to waste because, and i cant stress this enough, the game mechanics are terrible. If you don't enjoy being mercilessly slaughtered by players 100 levels above you after watching your base that you poured hours into be demolished i recommend doing a PVE server. The change of pace is nice, and i love spawning in only to find out all the tames you spent a ton of resources and time acquiring completely gone as if a giant meteor hit the planet and wiped out all living creatures. I swear I must be some kind of masochist, because for some reason i feel honor bound to accomplish something on this game, however i feel the only thing i will accomplish in this game is discovering a deeper meaning for the emotion of despair. 9/10 would recommend.

ARK: Survival Evolved is a game that has captured my imagination and kept me enthralled for countless hours. From the moment I stepped onto the shores of its mysterious island, I was drawn into a world of peril, wonder, and endless possibilities.

One of the things I love most about ARK is its sense of immersion. The vibrant and diverse landscapes, teeming with life both ancient and fantastical, make every moment spent in the game feel like a grand adventure. From dense forests to soaring mountains to vast oceans, there's always something new to explore and discover.

But what truly sets ARK apart is its dynamic ecosystem. The ability to tame and ride dinosaurs, from the mighty T-Rex to the graceful Pteranodon, adds an exhilarating element of companionship and danger to the game. The thrill of bonding with these prehistoric beasts and using them to navigate the world is an experience unlike any other.

ARK also excels in its sense of progression and achievement. From humble beginnings as a stranded survivor, I've built thriving bases, mastered new technologies, and faced off against fearsome creatures and rival tribes. The sense of accomplishment that comes with overcoming challenges and growing stronger is incredibly rewarding and keeps me coming back for more.

Of course, no review of ARK would be complete without mentioning the vibrant community that surrounds the game. Whether teaming up with friends to conquer a treacherous cave or engaging in epic battles against rival tribes, the camaraderie and shared experiences make every moment in ARK feel meaningful and memorable.

In conclusion, ARK: Survival Evolved is a game that has truly captured my heart. Its vast and vibrant world, dynamic gameplay, and sense of community have made it an unforgettable journey. If you're looking for a game that offers endless adventure and excitement, look no further than ARK: Survival Evolved. It's a wild and wondrous experience that I can't recommend highly enough.

This post is a cry for help. I can‚Äôt stand this anymore. Everywhere I go, this stupid orange shitstain somehow finds me and ruins my life. No matter how many defense mechanisms I have, it always come back.

Yesterday, I was working at my job when I heard it. That fateful sound of a stat drop. I quickly leaped out of my chair and turned around, but the fucker had already used intimidate on all of my coworkers. I ran towards the bastard to punch him, but he set up stealth rocks in my cubicle, preventing me from working again. I quickly bolted to the office fridge to grab some ice cubes, but by the time I screamed ‚ÄúKYUREM USE ICE BEAM‚Äù the fucker had already u-turned out the window. I couldn‚Äôt work anymore because of the stealth rocks, so I had to leave so I could get a defog tm from my car.

As I grabbed the defog tm from my car, the thing jumped me from behind and used knock off, smacking the tm into the middle of the road. Before I could go grab it, a car raced by and crushed the tm, making it worthless. As I was standing there, shocked by what happened, the orange demon used earthquake on my car, giving me 4 flat tires simultaneously. Filled with rage, I grabbed a keldeo plush from my car, shoved a pair of spectacles onto its face, and hurled it at the thing, while screaming ‚ÄúKELDEO USE HYDRO PUMP.‚Äù Just like always, however, my hydro pump missed, and the fucker u-turned away again.

After I took a bus home, I was exhausted. As I was lying in my bed, depressed, my 6-year old daughter came into the room. She started talking about her favorite TV show, when suddenly, her face began to change. No. NO. As she continued talking, her face continued to morph, until it was identical to Landorus-Therian. I was ready this time, though. I quickly kicked off my shoes, revealing that I had duct-taped ice cubes to my feet. I then proceeded to triple axel the ever loving shit out of that thing. I looked up and screamed with joy, thinking it was all over. However, as I came to my senses, I saw my daughter unconscious on the floor and realized what I had done. The orange bastard had tricked me. My wife stood in the doorway, shocked, before she pulled out her phone and dialed 911. I‚Äôm writing this in the woods right now, the police are probably going to find me soon.

ARK: Survival Evolved is definitely a game best enjoyed with friends. It's like Minecraft with dinosaurs, offering a unique twist with its indie charm that's both its strength and weakness. While its indie roots add a certain appeal, they also bring challenges, making the game somewhat difficult to grasp at first. It can be frustrating if you're not sure what you're doing, but it also offers countless hours of engagement as you and your friends work together to figure things out. I give it a thumbs up, mainly because playing with friends adds so much to the experience. However, personally, it's more about the shared moments with friends than the game itself, especially as the developers shift their focus to new projects and leave community management wanting.

This is the most frustrating, the most unfinished and the most poorly optimized game I have ever played. With that said, this game is very special to me. Starting a new server with the boys is one of the most fun experiences I've had while gaming and I will never forget the crazy adventures I've had with my friends in ARK. There was this one time when two of my friends had covered a mountain in turrets and everyone else had to remember the exact location of that mountain if they didn't want to die. There was this one time when my tribe had to move 3 times in one day because one of our friends kept finding our base. I could go on forever because ARK Survival Evolved is one of my favorite survival games of all time even though I wouldn't call it a "great" game. ASA sucks right now but I believe it has the potential to learn from ASE's mistakes and become the perfect survival game, but until that happens, I will keep playing this crazy dino game instead.

Once upon a time in a kingdom far, far away, there lived a queen named [customer]. She was known for her grace, wisdom, and love for adventures. Despite her regal stature, she harbored a deep passion for gaming, a world that allowed her to escape the rigors of her royal duties.

One day, as she gazed into her enchanted scrying orb, she found herself transported into the digital realm of Steam. Confused and bewildered, she found herself standing in a marketplace filled with the shimmering allure of countless games. However, her attention was drawn to two games displayed on sale, both beckoning her with their promises of adventure.

As she peered into the orb of time, the two games materialized before her eyes. On one side, the lush landscapes of Ark Survival Evolved unfolded, filled with towering dinosaurs and untamed wilderness. On the other, the brutal and unforgiving world of Conan Exiles awaited her, promising a life of conquest and glory.

The queen, with her keen eye for detail, observed the graphics of both games. The landscapes of Conan Exiles were breathtaking, with vibrant, detailed environments that beckoned her to explore. The game allowed for stunning character customization, allowing her to embody a vision of regal beauty amidst the harsh world. She marveled at the intricate combat animations for each weapon, from the graceful arcs of a sword to the thunderous impact of a warhammer. The attention to detail in Conan Exiles set it apart, making the world come alive in a way that captivated her senses.

With a resolute nod, she made her decision, choosing Conan Exiles for its unparalleled beauty, attention to detail, and the promise of immersive combat experiences.

In an instant, she found herself immersed in the rugged terrain of Conan Exiles, her royal garments replaced by the attire of a warrior queen. Determined to prove her choice right, she rallied the people of the land to her cause, inspiring them with her wisdom and unwavering leadership.

As she delved deeper into the game, she encountered treacherous foes, harsh environments, and daunting challenges. Yet, with her tactical prowess and unyielding spirit, she led her people to victory after victory, establishing a mighty empire that stood as a testament to her strength and wisdom.

Throughout her journey, she encountered the inhabitants of the Conan universe, explaining to them why her choice of Conan Exiles over Ark Survival Evolved was the right one. She demonstrated the virtues of her chosen game, showcasing the depth of its world, the richness of its lore, and the satisfaction of its conquests.

As the days turned into years within the game, the queen faced countless trials, each one a testament to her resilience and unwavering determination. She fought valiantly, strategized cunningly, and united the people of the land under her banner.

Finally, after what felt like a lifetime, the queen emerged victorious, having conquered the challenges of Conan Exiles. As she stood atop the grand citadel she had built, she knew that her time in the digital realm had come to an end.

With a flash of light, the queen found herself back in the real world, the scrying orb glowing softly. As she gazed upon it, a sense of satisfaction filled her heart, for she had proven her wisdom and strength, both in the game and in the choice she had made.

And so, the queen's tale became a legend, a story of resilience, triumph, and the unfaltering spirit of a ruler who had transcended the boundaries of the digital world. Her choice of Conan Exiles over Ark Survival Evolved had not only led her to victory but had also cemented her legacy as a queen of unmatched wisdom and courage.

Fun and immersive.  Unfortunately, well-known bugs were not addressed in this version; you have to pay for Ascended if you want resolution.  You get what you pay for - MMOs that take your money monthly will always have better support.  Poor collision and resource node despawn can cripple nondedicated/solo play if you don't know to alter the settings first.  You will learn to hack this game's save files and rebound from devastating issues - be prepared for a metagame as compelling, intense, and stressful as the game itself.  Cannot recommend due to known unresolved issues.  Buy Ascended instead.

Ark Survival Evolved offers an immersive, exhilarating adventure set in a stunning prehistoric world. With its vast landscapes teeming with dinosaurs and other prehistoric creatures, the game provides endless opportunities for exploration and discovery. The level of detail in creature designs and environments is breathtaking, truly bringing the world to life. The gameplay mechanics, including crafting, building, and taming dinosaurs, are deep and rewarding, allowing players to carve out their own unique experiences. The multiplayer aspect adds another layer of excitement, as players can team up to tackle challenges or engage in thrilling PvP battles. With regular updates and a passionate community, Ark Survival Evolved continues to evolve and impress, making it a must-play for fans of survival and adventure games alike

I absolutely love this game with my heart. I have around 1000 hours between two accounts and It's an absolute masterpiece of a game. I love it but I can't deny all the issues this game and It's developer/publisher have. The game has it all, loving (but very toxic) community, an interesting story, and good DLCs, but the one thing the game doesn't have is developers that care. I hope something changes in the future, but it probably won't. I would give this game a thumbs up, but after all the drama I got to give it a thumbs down.

UPDATE Feb 2024: Do not buy this piece of shit! They haven't fixed any bugs, and have left this game as still in early access but moved on. Then they've repackaged this piece of shit as Ark Survival Acended! Let me tell you, a piece of crap with prettier graphics is still a piece of crap. Do not be tempted into giving this shit company any money!
UPDATE Sep 2022: Decided to try it again, see if anything has improved. Nah, it still sucks. Still a very long startup and still prone to crashes. And I noticed it takes like 330 GB on the hard drive! Other games I have installed are around 35 GB max. This is a bloated monster that doesn't even run properly. Unstalling again. Sigh.
UPDATE Feb 2021: I've been away from the game for a long while and decided to give it another chance. It should be better than it used to be, right? Nope. It is actually much much worse. 
My game keeps crashing my high-powered Alienware computer. As in, Windows freezes and I have to do a hard shutdown. It is totally unplayable. I play on my own singleplayer game, and I thought the crash was due to the one mod I installed from Steam, for Structures Plus, because when I would open the engrams window (containing both regular engrams and S+ engrams) everything would slow down to a crawl. So after the first freeze/crash I removed the mod. And by the way, that first crash wiped out my save game so I had to start completely over with a new survivor. It didn't take long for the computer to crash again. I give up.
Don't even bother playing this game, it is so unstable. You can put in a lot of effort just to have it all wiped out. Not worth it.

Previous review from 2019:
For solo play: no I would not recommend it. It has TOO MANY CARNIVORES TRYING TO KILL YOU to be able to do much of anything besides die die die. The amount of carnivores vs herbivores is entirely unrealistic. There is a way to create a list of dinos that when they spawn, they actually spawn as something else. That way you can choose the worst carnivores and have them instead spawn as, I dunno, sheep or trilobites or nothing at all. That cuts the carnivore population down and makes this playable. Look up 'NPCReplacements' command for game.ini file.
For group play: I haven't played in groups so I can only say this is really the only way to survive the  carnivores.

As a player, ARK: Survival Evolved offers an unparalleled adventure in a prehistoric world teeming with danger and discovery. From the moment you wake up on its mysterious shores, the game immerses you in a struggle for survival against dinosaurs, natural elements, and rival players. The vast, beautiful landscapes are both breathtaking and treacherous, providing endless opportunities for exploration and excitement.

ARK's crafting system allows for limitless creativity as you build shelters, tame and ride dinosaurs, and develop advanced technology to thrive in this unforgiving environment. The thrill of hunting powerful creatures or facing off against other players in PvP battles is unmatched, and the sense of accomplishment when you conquer the challenges of the wild is deeply satisfying.

However, ARK is not without its flaws. The game's steep learning curve can be daunting for newcomers, and the grind for resources and taming can feel repetitive at times. Server stability issues and occasional bugs can also detract from the overall experience.

Despite these shortcomings, ARK: Survival Evolved remains a captivating and immersive survival game that offers endless possibilities for adventure and exploration. Whether you're playing solo or teaming up with friends, the thrill of surviving and thriving in this untamed world is an experience like no other.

So.... ARK..... Where do I start.....

I hate to admit it, but I've never actually explored the true late game of ARK with Tek and all that fancy tech stuff - I haven't even fought a boss. This game unfortunately is one of few out there that can be 100%'d with console commands, which is an absolute shame, and is by far my biggest problem with this game - please update the achievements for future players so these can be truly earned! Ah who cares, Ascended is out and nothing will probably change.

Now it probably sounds like I hate ARK and honestly - I don't, I've been playing it on and off on console platforms for years now and the gameplay loop of building up bases and taming crazy dinos has always been extremely satisfying, and is 200% more fun with friends on a private server.

I've not bothered with the multiplayer when it comes to joining random servers on the browser, games that offer that functionality like ARK, Rust, Tarkov, and others haven't been my thing - but if you like that gameplay, this game will work well.

As for the gameplay down to the nitty gritty - I have a love/hate relationship with ARK. On one hand, I enjoy always having something to work towards and ARK is always able to do that for me; there's s many damn things to do in this game that I never could get bored. Plus the differing levels of challenge when it comes to what dinos you tame has always been a fun thing for me. My all time favorite ARK dino has always been one people love to hate - the Troodons. They stun you and kill you extremely fast, and you have to let 'em merc your tames to bring them on your side. I find that mechanic very interesting from a gameplay perspective, and while Troodons in the end are not the most stand out dino, they serve as some of the best dinos at your disposal when it comes to taming future dinos.

On the contrary....... ARK's early game is fucking hard, and can feel unfair in many ways. There's the Troodons that come out at night and merc your ass. There's dinos that snatch your stuff. There's dinos that swim and walk on land while being the size of a T-Rex. This game is brutal if you're not careful in the beginning, and having to gather even one or two specific materials for an item early to mid game (fucking crystals I swear,,,) can feel like you're risking it all for nothing.

ARK is without a doubt, a fun game, and luckily seems a lot better put together than it's unstable brother ARK Ascended. There's countless amounts of fun DLC for this game as well offering great and expansive maps, in addition to some super cool creatures and critters. If you're looking for a fun and challenging survival game, ARK is certainly a standout in the hit or miss genre that is survival games. If you're looking for a fun game to play with friends, then definitely check this one out!

Ark: Survival Evolved isn't just a game, it's a time-sucking vortex that devours your life faster than a hungry T-Rex gobbles up a goat. From the moment you wash up on that forsaken island, you can kiss your real-world responsibilities goodbye.

Say farewell to personal hygiene because who has time for showers when you're too busy dodging raptor attacks and taming a Brontosaurus? Your family might wonder why you smell like a swamp creature, but hey, at least your virtual tribe thinks you're a hero.

Ark survival evolved, where do I begin with this one. I guess I should point out that across windows and steam ASE is my 2nd most played game ever. I hate that I love this game. It's like crack. It's so bad and yet I couldn't stop playing it. Something about it just itches that inner child in me; I love to explore, I love to build, and I even moreso love dinosaurs I can be friends with. I had a whole community to play with, I hosted a server cluster, we had drama and politics, territory and conflicts, boss fights and resource missions. It was incredible. We also had insanely high level dinos hand-bred for weeks to be the absolutely positively best dinos you could get. Despite that, it was still somehow barely enough to beat bosses. I sincerely felt grief when I lost because losing dinos you spend weeks raising is crushing, and after finally beating them, it was a triumph like no other. You got rare and powerful tech from beating each boss, and fighting through the dungeons for the artifacts to fight the bosses was also hell on earth. 

For the cons of this game? The building system (my favorite thing to do is build) was awful, optimization is pain, and building with non-mod/vanilla stuff is the definition of agony. Flying and wyverns are rather OP though I'd argue the process of obtaining them is almost difficult enough to justify it. This game somehow rolls the best parts of survival builder games in with the worst aspects of it; A cancerous community (I stuck to my small public server cluster of 4-10 people), very slow bug patches (some of which never have been patched) and an offensively massive download of 400gb. The game doesn't even look pretty enough to break 100gb, like seriously wtf! 

Anyways, I digress, if you like dinosaurs, got 15 bucks, a NASA computer, and some friends to run through the jungle with, you might just love this game.

A FANTASTIC SURVIVAL GAME...RUINED BY GREED

ARK Survival Evolved is hands down one of the greatest multiplayer survival games ever created.  Despite Studio Wildcard's inexperience with game development, they produced a game that thousands of people could enjoy.  Whether you loved to mod, explore a vast and complicated world, challenge yourself with tough solo play, work as part of a larger tribe, or just wanted to have your own dinosaur, this game had a little of something for every player.

Then Studio Wildcard and its parent company, Snail Games, went off the deep end.  Updates were constantly delayed.  Cheaters ran rampant on official servers with developers purposely turning a blind eye to - and, in some cases, helping - such players (namely Chinese players).  Instead of putting the majority of their resources into producing the long-awaited "ARK: Survival Ascended" revamp or ARK II, the developers chose to waste their time and resources with animated spin-offs and throwing their hat into the political arena.  They demanded more money from their customers while continuing to withhold products.  They lie to investors.  They blame the community when consumers give them any kind of feedback that is not downright praise and adoration.

Do I recommend this game?  With the official servers expected to be shut down this year in preparation for a game projected to be completed in mid-2024 to early 2025, I do not recommend playing this game outside of single player unless you are open to paying a third party to host an online server.  If you are adamant about trying this game out, I recommend waiting until it is on sale or just wait for ARK: Survival Ascended (or ARK II) to come out.  If you just want to watch someone else play the game so you can at least get an idea of what it is like, I suggest watching someone else play the game on Twitch or YouTube (I personally recommend Neebs Gaming, Syntac, or Arahli the Geek).

After putting a debatable amount of gametime into this piece of art, I think I owe a little review.
I downloaded this game in 2015 and after some - moderate - server problems, I actually started playing this game in 2018 - not because the server problems were fixed, but because I actually got told "you have to wait through the 6 minute loading time, its not a bug its a feature". 
So there I go finally playing the desired game and I have to admit it completely catched me in the first minutes.
Despite dieing like 20 times in the first 10 minutes and then doing a - patented, incredibly smart - Gamer move and actually starting in the recommended starting zone, the graphics and game design not only blew my PC up but also my mind.

I don't want to talk about the gameplay to much since, depending on what kind of combat you prefer (PVP, PVE, Boss fights), you can go to different servers or even create your own one.

Overall I would 100% buy it again and therefore rate it a solid 9,5/10 (-0,5 because loading time still goes brrrrr)
Tip: if its big then its totally safe :)

In the ethereal realm where beauty converges with perfection, I find myself grappling with the inadequacy of words to encapsulate the awe-inspiring spectacle before me. This magnificent creation is not merely an object of admiration; it is a transcendent experience, an opulent tapestry woven with threads of unparalleled artistry and craftsmanship.

To describe this masterpiece as beautiful would be an egregious understatement. It is a symphony of aesthetics that eludes the grasp of conventional language, leaving one in a state of profound speechlessness. Each facet, each contour, and every meticulously crafted detail seem to dance in harmony, creating a visual opulence that defies the limitations of mere description.

The sheer ingenuity displayed in the conception of this marvel is a testament to the boundless imagination of its creators. It is as though they summoned inspiration from the very cosmos, channeling divine elegance into the earthly realm. The result is a creation that transcends the boundaries of the tangible, inviting contemplation on the sublime nature of artistic genius.

As my eyes trace the contours of this divine opus, I am acutely aware that I am in the presence of something extraordinary, something that transcends the mundane and ascends into the realm of the extraordinary. The lines between reality and the surreal blur, as if the very fabric of existence is woven with the threads of this exquisite creation.

Attempting to dissect the elements that compose this masterpiece feels akin to dismantling a delicate sonnet or dissecting the hues of a resplendent sunset. The harmonious convergence of form and substance in this creation resists reductionism, beckoning the beholder to surrender to the ineffable allure of its perfection.

In the presence of such ineffable beauty, one is compelled to marvel at the limits of human ingenuity. This creation stands as a testament to the heights that can be reached when artistic vision intertwines with consummate skill. It is not a mere object; it is a magnum opus, an artifact of sublime proportions that leaves an indelible imprint on the canvas of aesthetic appreciation.

In the face of this immaculate creation, I find myself at a loss, for words falter in the attempt to encapsulate the splendor that unfolds before my eyes. It is a tapestry woven with threads of transcendence, a testament to the infinite potential of human creativity. In the presence of such divine artistry, silence becomes the most profound form of homage.

[h1]Crafting a Dinosaur Dynasty: My Tales from ARK[/h1]

[h2]Overview:[/h2]
After dedicating over 4,660 hours on Steam to ARK: Survival Evolved, my experience transcends mere gameplay; it's an expansive odyssey in a futuristic world where dinosaurs roam and survival is a high-tech art.

[h2]Gameplay and Customization:[/h2]
[b]The Power of Mods:[/b] The game's robust mod support turns ARK into an ever-evolving universe. These player-created modifications have perpetually refreshed my experience, introducing new and exciting elements that redefine gameplay.

[b]Community at the Core:[/b] The ARK community forms the heartbeat of the game. Sharing strategies for base building, cooperating in dinosaur taming, and uniting for boss battles exemplify the strong communal spirit that has enriched my journey in ARK.

[b]Engaging and Immersive Gameplay:[/b] Every session in ARK is an adventure, filled with the excitement of fortifying futuristic bases, nurturing prehistoric and exotic creatures, and preparing for grandiose boss fights. The game masterfully balances exploration thrills with the satisfaction of strategic building and progression.

[h2]The World of ARK:[/h2]
[b]Diverse Biomes and Challenges:[/b] ARK presents a diverse array of environments, from lush jungles to stark wastelands, each with unique challenges and discoveries. The excitement of exploration is augmented by the beauty and peril of these futuristic landscapes.

[b]Dinosaur Taming and Breeding:[/b] At the heart of ARK is the fascinating process of taming and breeding a vast array of dinosaurs and other creatures. This aspect of the game offers deep engagement and a sense of accomplishment that is truly unparalleled.

[h2]Personal Reflection:[/h2]
From my first steps into ARK's advanced yet primitive world, I was captivated. The game is a testament to the excitement of futuristic survival and the joys of creative mastery. It's more than just a game; it's a journey into a world where the distant past and advanced future collide, offering endless possibilities and challenges.

[h2]Final Verdict:[/h2]
ARK: Survival Evolved is an exceptional game, offering a unique blend of high-tech adventure, creative building, and community-driven experiences. Whether you‚Äôre a veteran survivor or a newcomer, ARK promises an experience that is as rewarding as it is challenging.

I have always enjoyed Ark, I remember when it was first released, the graphics were something else and it ticked every box I had when it came to game, DINOSAURS, GUNS, SURVIVAL, BUILDING, EXPLORATION, AND YOU COULD RIDE THE DINOSAURS. I finally got it with my pocket money, took me a day to actually install it, and then an hour on the loading screen but I was in.........and........it ran with 1 fps.....I was a kid with a crappy little laptop....I was ruined....a wreck...oh it was unbearable.....I watch endless YouTube videos jealous of all these gamers able to sit and enjoy this game. Years later I heard the news, XBOX RELEASE, oh my, so I pre-ordered it.....then the wait, it was so long. Then multiple delays, I was fuming, then all of a sudden one Thursday night, a message was received from the store, my mother drove me down the hill and we went in to EB games where I was handed a box, ARK. I had it in my hands. After all these years, My journey was complete, I came home, installed the bugger and opened it up. I was finally here. The memories I had when I first played the game, I wish I could feel them again. My first base, my first T-Rex (Pebbles) Rest in Peace buddy. I was obsessed with the game. Now years later, I'm in my 20s and I'm finally able to run the bugger on my PC, a game I bought in 2015 on steam yet probably wasn't able to play on PC until a few years back, obviously minus the console edition. sure its full of bugs but same as for a lot of people, Ark holds a special place in peoples hearts, especially anyone who was a fan of the DINOTOPIA books as a kid.

In the crucible of relentless struggle, after numerous tribulations and setbacks, it was accomplished! The Island stood in all its completed glory, a testament to perseverance and defiance against the harsh fauna.

My journey took me to Scorched Earth, an inhospitable realm where my problems where many. But one stood out: an invisible, perilous, inescapable enemy lurked all around me... the heat. 

I materialised in what seemed like a benign corner of the map. Little did I know that danger lurked in the shadows. As if they were just waiting for me, in an instant, two Raptors emerged beside me, casting me into the abyss of the main menu as I sought another spawning location.

The cycle of survival unfolded: punch tree, craft pickaxe, gather stone, craft axe, erect a 2x2 stone sanctuary. Yet, the unforgiving heat rendered stone structures unbearable. Wood proved futile, and metal seemed an insurmountable challenge. After consulting the old scriptures, thatch was the way to go until I discovered Adobe.

An Argy, a formidable ally, was tamed and whispered her name: "FEM-107"; coincidentally, she was a level 107 Female Argy. 

I had to know everything about this place. No location was to stay undiscovered. Mounting FEM-107, we soared through the skies on a discovery mission, killing all predators I could find in my path; she was an exquisite killing machine. Life was good.

Scriptures foretold of a location where flying beasts lived and thrived away from the eyes and knowledge of this scorched place.
Alas, a perilous crevice teeming with Wyverns was found. Curiosity and courage took the best of me. I am not one to flee from hardship. 

We flew too bravely; too close. Tragedy struck; A group of 15(ish) wyverns spoted us. 
Hope was lost. Fleeing was not an option. They were to fast. 

Tragedy struck.

I perished, losing all collected loot. But worse of all, FEM-107 was gone forever. I would never again look at those bright eyes and silky feathers. No longer would we feel the wind in our faces while tormenting predatory fauna. 

Another consultation with the old scriptures revealed these wyverns have eggs that can be hatched. I may still find solace in capturing one 

Undeterred, I tamed four other Argies; I could not bear myself to name them as they would probably share FEM-107's fate. But I would prepare beforehand. 

Terrorising began once again. My squad became a menace. We became a perfectly oiled killing machine. Nothing survived. No distinctions between predators or others was relevant anymore. Increasing health and melee was the only paramount objective. 

Finally when everyone was level 150+. I took my squad and began the venture to my old grave.

Returning to the wyvern lair, I confronted the imminent danger of retrieving coveted eggs. 

2 were found. 2 were stolen. Poison and Lightning. 

We were able to withstand the first wave of wyverns. But we were too weak to handle the second wave. Amid the chaos, three Argies fell, and I barely escaped the blinding agony of a heat-induced demise that looked like an acid trip of blur and colours. Scriptures were consulted and I found out this is caused by heatstroke.

With my sole surviving Argy, I embarked on the journey home, fuelled by the burning desire to hatch those wyvern eggs, that was the next objective - NAY! - the singular, all-encompassing objective. I would not hit another stone or tree before hatching those eggs.

Eventually, scriptures were consulted and a makeshift "bed" of 20 campfires had to be constructed for this endeavour.

The Poison egg, mistakenly placed in my "belt" inventory, was CONSUMED in a regrettable mishap.

Undeterred, I turned my attention to the Lightning egg. Placed meticulously on the fiery bed of campfires, finally, the incubation process began‚Äîa torturous 45-minute wait, an eternity in the mind.

Fuelling the fires as the countdown dwindled. Ten minutes, five minutes, three minutes, one... anticipation reached its zenith.

It hatched! A triumphant moment tainted by unforeseen peril‚Äîmy newly hatched wyvern was ablaze! Immobilised amidst the searing campfires, it suffered fiery torment, unable to escape.
Desperation surged through me like an unstoppable force. Commands to "follow me" went unanswered. As the fires were manually extinguished, the infant wyvern gazed at me, its eyes pleading for salvation, a silent scream echoing within. In its final moment, it fixed its gaze upon me, and with a whisper that cut through the air and shattered my soul, it uttered, "Wow...  you are a stupid noob!"

Ark: Survival Evolved has carved its place in the survival gaming genre, offering an expansive open-world teeming with prehistoric wonders. My experience, primarily in PvE, has been a rollercoaster of excitement and challenges.

The game's crown jewel is undoubtedly its replayability. The vast, dynamically generated landscapes and the plethora of creatures make every playthrough unique. The thrill of taming, breeding, and building keeps drawing players back for more.

While I've explored the depths of the game in PvE, the diverse ecosystems, from dense jungles to frozen tundras, contribute to its lasting appeal. The cooperative aspect of PvE, where players band together against the dangers of the environment, adds an extra layer of enjoyment.

However, the transition when Snail Games Company acquired Ark brought a mixed bag of reactions. While the developers continue to introduce fresh content and updates, some players have expressed concerns about the impact on the game's direction.

Despite these uncertainties, credit is due to the development team for their ongoing commitment to enhancing the gaming experience. The intricate balance between survival and progression, the introduction of new creatures, and the constant optimization efforts showcase their dedication to the evolving world of Ark.

In conclusion, Ark: Survival Evolved remains a captivating journey into the prehistoric unknown. The undeniable replayability in PvE and the ongoing commitment of the development team make it a survival game worth exploring, despite the challenges introduced by the change in ownership.

The game is cool but also has some really disturbing elements like the ability to capture other players, put them in a cage, force feed them, drug them and generally abuse them forever in theory. I thought it was some exploit but this is apparantly "intended" and happens on official servers. You can have fun solo or with friends... just know the game is also the ultimate psychopath sandbox.

It's a good game, but it could be better. The A.I. was assembled with little to no thought whatsoever. The Carnivores attack anything and gobble it up, even engaging in fights until they die instead of running away (although a mod Zoology should fix these, I haven't been able to make the damn engrams work). The carnivores also never get fed up, leading to "terraforming", where carnivores dominate the land living in peace with each other, but killing every herbivore that spawns. Given the size and beauty of the worlds, this is probably ok, since I can't imagine the extra machine power it would take to power such huge maps as well as a decent A.I on every living thing. But it is not realistic. Taming something is like going to the shop and buying a doll. They mean nothing, they understand nothing. They stay still forever if you tell them and won't defend themselves if you tell them. They don't know what fleeing is or even how to stay in a certain area. Thank god for fences, but i'd be fine with just a leash or equivalent mechanic. The crown for dumb A.I take the bats. They know nothing except how to aggro toward a player and stand in the air. Some cave exploring.

Some creatures are ridiculously overpowered and give almost nothing in return. Early on, when I met the Daeodon and the Wolf, I simply couldn't win (metal armor). The Wolves attack very fast with huge knockback and eat mammoths by the truckload. I certainly couldn't kill two of them on my own, before I used good tames. Oddly enough, they spawn in the desert with thick fur, but the desert is 40¬∞C. Preposterous. The Daeodon has huge health, knockback and regeneration, but you'll only get about 10 each of meat/skin. Ridiculous. Carnos are much easier and give prime meat. I feel cheated. Butfrustrated, even.

There is something very off about some domesticated species and their wild counterparts. Parasaurs and stegos run much faster wild, but their speed is cut down significantly when you tame them (stegos especially). There are many examples of this, like the flying Tapejara, which sprints regally away but is half as fast when you tame it. Some get faster after taming. What were they thinking?

I have other minor complaints, why do baby dinos eat so much damn food, enough for a hundred dinos? Why are dinos such a statistic devoid of life? Why do wolves get a packleader aura and hunt in packs, but not Utahraptors? Where the hell is my pizza? Why am I such a failure? Why are there 4 T-Rexes outside my door ON A SNOWY MOUNTAIN?
It reminds me of squid games

This is a review from a single player perspective.

The game is ruthless. You have to have a huge herd of strong dinos to have a chance to get anywhere, and even then you're likely to get killed by some tiny bullshit enemy because your herd gets stuck in itself.

If you dare to venture out from your starting location there's a good chance you meet something that can slay a good amount of dinos so even if you bring an army, it might be too small for a single enemy and you're screwed again.

I've spent so many hours in this game, mostly in coop with one other player, and every time I pick it up again I have fun for maybe 20 hours, before I remember why I hate the game and uninstall it. 

And the size of the game... Jesus, it's pretty good looking but not 250GB worth.

Verdict: 2/10. Would not recommend to my worst enemy.

ARK stands out as a beautifully crafted game, where I find enjoyment in nearly every aspect. Undoubtedly, it poses a significant challenge for newcomers, demanding a steep learning curve. However, for those persistent enough to delve into its complexities, the realization dawns that, despite its difficulty, the game offers immense fun and provides an avenue to immerse oneself for hours, days, and even months into a captivating world filled with dinosaurs.

The game's allure is further heightened when shared with friends. Whether played on official, unofficial, dedicated, or non-dedicated servers, the cooperative element enhances the overall experience. The camaraderie adds an extra layer of enjoyment, turning what could be a solitary adventure into a shared endeavor.

Moreover, the inclusion of mods significantly contributes to the game's versatility. These modifications not only introduce fun elements but also serve as valuable tools, facilitating tweaks that may simplify certain aspects or, conversely, intensify the challenge for those seeking a more demanding gameplay experience. Notable examples, such as Primal Fear and Dino Overhaul X, fundamentally alter the game mechanics, offering a refreshing and thoroughly different gameplay encounter.

In essence, ARK not only presents a visually stunning and challenging gaming experience but also underscores the adaptability and longevity that arises from its diverse player-driven and mod-supported features

It's essential to note that the beauty of ARK lies not just in its visual appeal but also in the game's flexibility that empowers players to shape and design their own experience. The capacity to customize and tweak various aspects to align with personal preferences contributes significantly to the game's allure. This level of creative control allows players to tailor the gameplay to their liking, enhancing the overall beauty of the gaming experience. Whether through subtle adjustments or more profound modifications, this freedom to mold the game according to individual preferences adds a unique layer of beauty and engagement to ARK

Ark: Survival Evolved has been more than just a game for me; it's been a lifeline during some of the toughest moments in my life. While my 400+ hours were clocked on Xbox, the impact it had on me transcends platforms which is why I wanted to post this review, as I now have a PC capable of running Ark: Survival Ascended

This survival masterpiece not only catapulted me into a prehistoric world teeming with dinosaurs but also served as my digital sanctuary during challenging times. When reality felt overwhelming, Ark provided a haven where I could build, explore, and, most importantly, escape.

The vibrant landscapes and awe-inspiring creatures became my companions in the virtual realm, offering a welcome distraction and a therapeutic outlet. The challenges of taming the wild and navigating the perilous environment mirrored the struggles I faced in reality, yet the triumphs within the game fuelled a sense of accomplishment that resonated beyond the screen.

The community, both on Xbox and beyond, played an unexpected role in my journey. The shared experiences, cooperative efforts, and occasional PvP battles created connections that were surprisingly profound. Ark wasn't just a game; it was a community that understood and supported, even if only through the shared love for surviving in a world filled with dinosaurs.

As I migrate from Xbox to Steam, the memories forged in Ark remain without a doubt some of the best in my gaming history. This isn't just a review; it's a heartfelt thank you to Studio Wildcard for crafting a game that transcends pixels and becomes a lifeline for those in need of a digital escape.

If you're searching for a game that offers more than just entertainment, Ark: Survival Evolved is a journey worth taking. It's not just about survival; it's about finding solace and strength in the most unexpected places.

Great game especially if you were interested in prehistoric wildlife as a child.  A steady stream of rich content was pumped into this game since its release, as well as an active modding community.  Sometimes, Ark: Survival Evolved makes me feel like I have 20/40 vision even though I'm wearing $2,000 glasses, because graphics performance is not well optimized.  Graphics optimization seemed to be a much lower priority than game content.  I use a desktop computer with high-end hardware.  This game was part of the reason I got a more powerful GPU.  However, my performance improvements were marginal.  This is the only game I play which I feel the need to use resolution upscaling.  Ark: Survival Evolved makes me appreciate other games which are well-optimized.  It makes me appreciate efficient programmers and video game studios who prioritize performance optimization.  I watch various Youtubers' recordings of Ark and very few of them run the game at "epic" settings with smooth performance.  High-end GPUs struggle to run Ark smoothly at higher resolutions.  The vast majority of recorded Ark content and time spent playing Ark is rendered with low in-game settings, utilization of older shader models, past versions of DirectX API, and low memory modes.

     However, I enjoy playing Ark.  Hahaha

Ark: Survival Evolved is an absolute gem of a game. The immersive open-world environment, filled with stunning landscapes and prehistoric creatures, creates a truly unique and thrilling experience. The crafting system adds depth to gameplay, and taming dinosaurs provides a great sense of accomplishment. The multiplayer aspect is where the game truly shines, allowing for epic adventures and creating a sense of camaraderie. The graphics and visuals are stunning, and the attention to detail is impressive. Overall, Ark: Survival Evolved is a must-play for fans of the survival genre. While Ark: Survival Evolved has its strengths, there are also some downsides to consider. The steep learning curve can be overwhelming, especially for newcomers to the survival genre. The game's performance can be inconsistent, with occasional frame rate drops and visual glitches. Additionally, the lack of hand-holding or guidance can leave players feeling lost and frustrated. Despite its flaws, Ark: Survival Evolved still offers an immersive experience with its open-world environment and challenging gameplay mechanics. However, these issues should be taken into account before diving into the game.

There are so many ways to play and enjoy this game. The options for how to build, craft item's, play style and dino army creation are diverse. You can choose to try for bosses or completely ignore them, create a community for friends, build an economy in game with trading outposts, a large number of mods available that open up even more options and improve q.o.l. from slightly to enormously. And... Yes, sometimes there are crashes and you could lose items/dinos in them. It can be a bit disheartening but it's a game. Make back-ups, breed pairs, etc and you'll be ok. I love this game and the amount of effort that the devs have put into adding to the experience over the years. They listen to and interact with the community very well.

Good survival game, lots of building and dinos to kill and capture. But the AI in the game really needs work. 

My only complaint is almost every single dino in the game; when they see you; comes after you. This is terrible. I mean omg! It ruins the game when there is 3 herds of dinos not attacking each other, but they all come after YOU! I had to finally stop playing it. 

The attack distance needs to be increased or there needs to be some kind of passive chance they won't attack you every time. I can remember the last time I played and I was flying a bird over a mountain and was close enough to the ground, but still high enough; I was scouting and needed to land. Turns out I aggro every dino along the way and 20 dinos come running over the hill and kill me!!

Seriously?? This is messed up? Why hasn't this been balanced and addressed yet?

Overall it is fun. But frustrating...

I'm revamping my review. ARK: SURVIVAL EVOLVED is a masterpiece, and honestly, I can't wait to play ASA, when I get it. The graphics are extremely good, and the settings are greatly configurable. SFX is amazing, sounds like actual dinosaurs, to be honest. I don't know what dinosaurs sound like. The mechanics, engram system, building, fighting, and taming is all really fun. The best part is the modding capabilities of ASE. I'd recommend to just buy ASA, but you can buy ASE too, unless you already have it. In general, the game is great. Just really large, and expansive. Buy ASE or ASA if you'd like.

It may seem like i only have 20 hours on this game but i assure you i have thousands of hours. i used to be an xbox player so i played on the other version with a different account. This game is a rollercoaster of emotions every time you sit down to play it. You will never feel higher highs or lower lows. You will dream and think about ark of every hour of your existence. It is a craving that is never satisfied. Until, one day, you log on to go see your family of dinosaurs that have replaced your actual family, only to see that your world has been erased. vanished in the blink of an eye. So thinking its a bug you start from square one again. ONLY FOR THE CYCLE TO REPEAT. you then begin the 5 stages of grief and never pick up ark again. The betrayal is too much, the loss of your loved ones over and over weighs far too heavy on your heart. 
Ark is the best game you will ever play. It is also the worst game you will ever play.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2020 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
Taming dinos is fun and my wife enjoys it too. So I guess it's fun for the whole family.

it seems Ark has gotten alot of bad reviews recently, based off of the fact they released a paid dlc and fixed the character server changing that everyone has been complaining about an asking for. i see alot of reviews saying the game is buggy/glitchy/laggy what have you. i have owned this game since about the first week it has came out. i played for a few months then took a break an came back to it. The devs have done an outstanding job on this game, from bringing new dinos and engrams to fixing different bugs. to bringing out new content regularly, i to was upset about having to pay 20$ for the dlc content when i as well as many others have been apart of this games making since the beginning. But heres the thing either they bring out content to make money off of or the game will end up like so many other early access games an just get abandonded due to lack of funds.  this game does not deserve bad reviews due to the fact you have to pay for dlc or even the fact it has some minor gameplay errors (in early access) the game is Great an i do not regret buying it an i know many others who also do not regret it.

This game is probably in my top 5 favourite games, it may take alot of your time though it is good for my time at the moment since i don't work yet, but honestly this game needs way more lag issues and frame rates fixed including bugs with map textures, sounds, also taming with some creatures it takes way to long to wait for 5-10 hours so most people change that but half the time it still takes long and the creature could die from a number of reasons. 

The glitches such as getting stuck in rocks/mountains/structures and also loosing your stuff can be a real pain when you really need it. The amount of times I've had to deal with lag is just awful, luckly I can still run it on my PC though the CPU usage is taking up way too much on my PC possibly many others, I really suggest you lower the Sky effects/shadows.

Either way it's still a great game with amazing textures!! (Mines set to medium cause my PC lags to much for Epic) Which is a bummer but i'm still pleased to notice tiny fixes here and there. =) feel free to add me if you want to or you agree or for whatever reason haha. 

I totally recommend this to people that love nature, adventure, or love a challenge and have the time to play. But if your PC isn't strong enough and you don't spend much time on it then i don't recommend it. Hopefully the game will improve more in the future! 

Edit: I now work so I have less time for this game though I'm going to add some more info.
Prepare your Disk space, ARK literally eats it all, only get this when on sale or you have the money, If you want to play with others only choose people you trust to run with your server cause some people raid and are really nasty but not every game is perfect. Make sure your settings aren't always low or else it will glitch really bad sometimes. Hope this helps, Thank you for reading.

[h1] TL;DR: [/h1]

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

[h2] A Wildly Fun Survival Experience, Recommended BUT... [/h2]

[hr][/hr]

[h1] Detailed Review: [/h1]

[h2] 1. Narrative and Visuals (3/5): [/h2]
The narrative lacks depth, and visuals, though promising, suffer due to optimization issues.

[h2] 2. Gameplay and Unique Features (4/5): [/h2]
Despite design flaws, Ark: Survival Evolved offers a unique survival experience with dinosaurs and base building. The gameplay, however, is hampered by questionable design decisions.

[h2] 3. Optimization Woes (2/5): [/h2]
The game's eight-year history is marred by unaddressed bugs and constant optimization challenges. The devs prioritize spin-offs over fixing fundamental issues, making the experience infuriating for players.

[h2] 4. Soundtrack and Audio Design (4/5): [/h2]
An epic soundtrack and well-crafted sound design add a layer of immersion, redeeming some aspects of the game.

[h2] 5. Bugs and Technical Issues (2/5): [/h2]
Ark suffers from numerous bugs, highlighting the lack of care in game design. Combat feels like a face-slapping fest, breeding is unintuitive, and progression lacks cohesion.

[h2] 6. Replay Value and DLCs (5/5): [/h2]
The game's saving grace lies in its high replay value, especially when played with friends. DLCs, when played in chronological order, enhance the overall experience.

[h2] 7. Community and Modding (5/5): [/h2]
A strong community and vibrant modding scene add layers of creativity, fostering a more enjoyable experience. For me playing without mods is totally impossible as they fix some of the core issues of the game.

[h2] 8. Value for Money (4/5): [/h2]
Despite its flaws, the game offers value, especially when investing in DLCs. The chronological order of DLCs enhances the overall gaming journey. If possible try to get the bundle when its on sale


[h1] Personal Thoughts: [/h1]

This game had the potential to truly become one of the all-time greats, but the devs' apparent focus on profits over player satisfaction has hindered its evolution. Despite community dedication, the game remains plagued by bugs, optimization issues, and a lack of meaningful improvements. The core mechanics feel haphazardly designed, with little cohesion between systems. Studio Wildcard's repeated releases, including "Survival Ascended," fail to address these fundamental issues, relying on flashy graphics to mask underlying problems.

The game's only redeeming qualities are its dinosaur-themed gameplay and base building. However, these aspects alone cannot compensate for the frustrations imposed by poor game mechanics. The taming system is unintuitive, leveling and dinosaur stats seem arbitrary, and the spawning system lacks purpose. Combat boils down to mindless face-slapping, undermining the potential for engaging gameplay.

Studio Wildcard's approach to game development, evidenced by Ark, PixArk, and "Survival Ascended," reflects a missed opportunity. The studio prioritizes cash grabs and graphical appeal over meaningful improvements. Despite the community's decade-long hope for substantial enhancements, the developers appear content with an unfinished product.

In conclusion, Studio Wildcard's failure to address fundamental issues and iterate on game design leaves Ark: Survival Evolved as a testament to unfulfilled potential. The game's lasting appeal relies on community-generated content and mods rather than the studio's own efforts. Until significant improvements are made, this review stands as a critique of a game that could have been great but was ultimately exploited for financial gain.

It just ... really hurts to love the idea of a game with such an unrefined execution. I don't even play pvp or online, I'm just a simple single player kinda person. But every time I get the itch for a game where I can tame/breed/ride animals and explore large maps and make awesome builds and bases this game is the ultimate answer. There are literally no other games like it that scratch that itch for me.

I always end up taking breaks from it and forgetting the admin codes to fix bugs, which mods to use, the order the mods have to be to prevent more bugs, relearn how to mess with the ini files which are hell (for me anyway) to learn again later. If you're fine with doing all this and relearning what's changed every time you pick it back up then I can't recommend ark enough, but people don't normally have to do this for a game that isn't in beta anymore.

At least a quarter of my hours spent in this game have been tweaking settings, mods and ini files just to make the game enjoyable. (my hardware is not the issue here, haha)

I just want a game that works without learning how to fix it myself. I'm not holding onto the hope that Ark Survival Ascended will be much better either tbh. I'm going to keep playing, I don't regret buying this game. But I wouldn't recommend it to new players.

I'm a long time console player, easily over 1k hours on official and another 1k on private clusters. This game is so fun and is def. worth buying to to try it out. The main issue is performance. Coming from console its not even a close contest, this PC runs the game a million times better but I will still take a dip in frames if Im loading near a bunch of spam (bunch of buildings laid out to block enemies from building close to your base) or a fully built base rendering in.

The concept is amazing and with a group of 4-5 people this game is truly on a whole other level. That being said Wild Card has been a trash company in regards to ASA and fixxing issues/bugs/cheaters with official servers, this is why alot of people play on "private" clusters where they can be more easily admin patrol'd.

This game is unique and this is why I like it. I give it a positive review for the multiple hours of enjoyment. However, you might wanna consider the following warnings before purchase :
- The game has been replaced by its remastered version : ARK Survival Ascended. As a result, this version is no longer updated or supported by the devs. 
- The official servers are no longer up. A few community-based servers are still running but no one can guarantee for how long since the game is no longer supported.
- The game has many glitches.
- The learning curve is extremely steep, and it can be discouraging for beginners. I strongly recommend learning the basis of the game in PVE before trying PVP and risking to see all your progress being wiped by other players. On the other hand, the depth of the game makes PVP one of the most rewarding experience I have ever experienced.

I played this game years ago on Xbox and whilst it wasn't perfect, it still ran better then than it does now on my high end laptop. I bought this game again thinking that over time the devs would have polished it and the bugs present back in the day would have been fixed. I also bought it to experience some nostalgia. To my surprise the game was actually worse now than it was then. My game crashed every 15/20 minutes to the point that it would no longer load a saved game or a new game without crashing. The store page also states that you need 60GB of free space for this game, this is a vast understatement as it takes up nearly 500GB of space, which in my opinion is a ridiculous amount of space for an older game.

Great game. Really lets you do whatever. Only thing I don't like is that you have to go around the ENTIRE island to collect necessary resources instead of staying in one general area. (12/11/23)

Edit 1: More than a year later, wow. I just wanna say the game is a lot more fun when you have good flyers like the argy and the quetz. Still think it's an AMAZING game. I would totally recommend it if you like sandbox games like MC, Terraria, Rust, etc. especially if you want a challenge. (12/22/21)
:)

Edit 2: So ig I have just started to edit this review annually. It's been 2 years since I first wrote this reviewn and I have over 300 hours of gameplay, so here's what I think. I still LOVE this game even though I don't play it nearly as much as I used to. I would definitely recommend this game as long as you have a good PC, since it easily brings my 3080 to the upper 80s and lower 90s (Celsius). If your wanting to get all the achievements in this game, be ready, some of it's achievements take can forever depending on how good (or bad) you are, which is why I don't have many achievements in ARK. It is an all around great game, though there are a ton of bugs. That's pretty much it -- hope you have fun!  9.3/10 (12/22/22)

Final Edit: Ark Survival Ascended has been out for a couple months by now. I don't think I'll be revisiting this ARK to be honest. ASA has been VERY fun and I just really enjoy it. I would still recommend this game for sure though, I have a ton of great memories from this game alone and it's easily a top 3 game imo. Anyways, goodbye ASE. o7 (12/27/23)

My only issue with this game is the amount of time you need to put into the game before you beat it.
There are multiple DLC maps that you can buy or install if you want to try something a bit different. From what I know there isn't any maps that have the exact same dinos on them. By that I mean of course they have some of the same dinos across the different maps. But some of the maps have more or less dino types than others, and some of them have dinos that you wouldn't see on the starter map, or some of the other map DLCs.

You can also play multiplayer if you buy a server, or you can join a random one for free.

Ark is a gaming disaster that has left me thoroughly frustrated and regretful. Attempting to join the game is an exercise in futility, with crashes greeting me at every turn, especially when trying to enjoy multiplayer with friends. The most infuriating part is the developers' neglect, seemingly prioritizing the hype around Ark 2 over fixing the glaring issues in the original game. It's a scummy marketing tactic that reeks of exploitation, deliberately leaving players in the lurch just to drive sales for the upcoming sequel. This experience has left me disillusioned and uninterested in any future Ark titles‚ÄîI won't be fooled into supporting such a shoddy gaming experience again.

I have a very love-hate relationship with this game. The ONLY reasons it is fun to play is because of co-op and community made mods. The base game is incredibly unoptimized, glitchy, boring, frustrating, and unbalanced. For a game that is so popular you'd think they'd fix these things, but instead the devs go on to make a NEW GAME claiming they're going to fix it. I highly doubt the new game will be all that better, but it won't stop me from hoping.

The DLCs to this game are honestly really cool. If you disregard the glitches and overall shittiness of the game it's super fun to learn about and play with friends. The cons outweigh the pros, but I still enjoy the game.

Plays like an MMO and runs like Guild Wars on a Pentium Hyper Threaded, this game is a mess.
There is a lot of material and experience grind, and the game play loop is definitely MMO inspired.
Party up on a high spec gaming pc, and you'll have an ok time. The console ports run very poorly.

[h3] +Pros [/h3]
+Dinosaurs
+Post launch support is great. Plenty of maps and they all vary, and updates frequently cause issues that are addressed in a quick fashion.
+So much stuff to build and do, this game goes from a tribal warmonger group with hatchets and slings to a insane group of kitted out SWAT operators zooming across the skies.
+Husbandry is very in depth.
+Workshop has mods that allow for EXTREME game play changes.

[h3] -Cons [/h3]
-The game play loop
-Server tool is extremely lacking in command line arguments. I would love to be able to manage objects, players, inventories etc etc but doing so isn't really possible, and if it is I haven't discovered it.
-System and storage requirements.

5/10 I don't like MMOs, but it has dinosaurs. It's an open world free form crafting and survival game. Runs poorly on every system I've played it on.

[h1]ARK: Survival Evolved Review[/h1]

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/346110/][/url]

[b]ARK: Survival Evolved[/b] is a game that lets you live out your childhood fantasies of being stranded on an island full of dinosaurs and other prehistoric creatures. You can craft tools, build shelters, tame beasts, and fight for survival in a vast open world.

While ARK has a lot of potential and some amazing moments, it also suffers from a number of issues that make it hard to recommend without reservations.

The game is poorly optimized and runs poorly on most systems, even on low settings. You'll experience frequent lag, stuttering, crashes, and bugs that can ruin your immersion and enjoyment.

The game also requires a lot of grinding and patience. You'll spend hours gathering resources, crafting items, building structures, and leveling up your character and your dinos. The game is very unforgiving and harsh, especially on PvP servers, where other players can raid your base, kill your dinos, and steal your stuff.

The game also lacks a clear direction and purpose. There's no real story or goal to follow, other than exploring the world and unlocking new technologies. The game relies on you to create your own fun and set your own goals, which can be appealing for some players, but boring and aimless for others.

If you're a fan of dinosaurs and survival games, and you have a powerful PC and a lot of patience, you might enjoy ARK and find it worth your time and money. But if you're looking for a polished and smooth game, or a game that has a clear direction and purpose, you might want to look elsewhere.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*]Beautiful and detailed world
[*]Variety of dinosaurs and other creatures
[*]Freedom and options
[*]Co-op and PvP modes
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*]Poor performance and optimization
[*]Frequent bugs and glitches
[*]Grindy and unforgiving gameplay
[*]Lack of direction and purpose
[/list]

[b]Rating:[/b] 6/10

Only way to not be tethered is $PAYING$ a monthly fee for a server rental.  With a small modification the DEV team should enable local server support w\o being tethered, if needed, limit to 3-5 players or something reasonable.  like many people looking for a MP game, I just want to play with 1-3 family members from random times and it fits for my family and friends.   If this solution was enacted i'd rate game at 9/10 and would recommend (considering minor glitches and what not's).  Until this solution is resolved i'd only rate this game as 4/10  Played for about 20-hrs and haven't touched since.
