When reviewing Ark I initially reviewed it positively. A sprawling survival game with the very unique mechanic to tame and ride dinosaurs, what is not to love? It is challenging and loads of fun with friends!


Then Wildcard sold us the Scorched Earth DLC before it left early access. "It is to help us pay for a lawsuit!" so I believed them.

Then Wildcard released 'Atlas', a sprawling ocean world that was similar to Ark but a totally new game! That is until it was shown to literally have the Ark menu in the game that Atlas was literally just a new map sold as an entirely new game... so I was skeptical. 

Then Wildcard sold us 'Extinction', their 'final' DLC that forced you to buy the season pass with all the other maps to play it, so I was distrustful.

Then Wildcard released Genesis 1/2 as entirely different season passes. I thought selling the original season pass to include 'all future dlcs' then switch it up to squeeze out more money from the fans was pure greed, so I all but lost faith in them.

Then Wildcard showed that their official pvp servers, which were a joke to begin with, had admins spawning in dinosaurs/items to help people from their parent company[Snail Games] get an advantage/sell said resources for real-world cash. So I gave up on Wildcard and focused on the community.

Then Wildcard appointed their forum moderator team, a [url=https://media.discordapp.net/attachments/876836735630340217/1187589645236715530/Ban.png?ex=6597700b&is=6584fb0b&hm=f399cb091326bc99f73e80064b045c0695913fcfa68109a811018395b3a91d5d&=&format=webp&quality=lossless&width=716&height=702]light hearted joke[/url] that said 'play along' to an unpopular thread was all it took, not against the guidelines by any means. Now a forum day ban is laid out in the rules as a warning for first time offenders, but it takes a lot of brain cells to combine words into a string of coherent thought, so they just slapped me with a perma-ban immediately. Appealed with steam and thought 'It happens, it was sorted out and the problem is resolved'. So I thought the moderator team was a bit prickly but the community would be worth it.

Several more helpful threads/comments in the community and I made a simple joke that since I was the [i]mighty[/i] steam level 38 that my opinion was more valid than others, poking fun at several people who claimed steam levels determined opinion quality. Not against the rules and since other people were doing it I assumed it was alright, all I did was [url=https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/876836735630340217/1085632490309427290/ban_2_message.png]quote a user[/url] and make a joke.

[h1]Every post I had ever made in the Ark forums for over half a decade was erased[/h1]
[i]Settings help, starter guides help, cute comments about how dinosaurs look adorable, troubleshooting help, and simple jokes back and forth with forum commentators. [/i]

To ban someone is one thing, even if you [url=https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/876836735630340217/1085632490573664377/users.png]selectively ban people(not banned/deleted)[/url] you dislike instead of banning everyone who breaks said rule (with the severity being based on your opinion of the person, like the person I quoted getting a 1-day after multiple offenses), it just makes it so that the user cannot post in the future. To delete all comments made by someone going out of their way to help others is such a spiteful thing to do that I can't help but feel ashamed I ever put time in this game to begin with. You did it Wildcard, you make the community a joke. [Yes, a bit dramatic but I do feel just a tad bit betrayed that Wildcard just stopped caring about who drove the community bus]

[h1]Edit: Wrote 3 tickets to Ark support.[/h1]
1) Thought the permaban for my first offense was a bit heavy handed and plus I saw quite a few comments get deleted that were following the rules so I wrote ark support about it. [url=https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/876836735630340217/1085707707815825478/appeal_1.png]'Read the rules lmao'[/url]

2) I tried to appeal my 2nd ban[appealed the first through steam] through Ark support. I provided evidence that nothing I said was wrong and that I didn't deserve the ban. I was told [url=https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/876836735630340217/1085707828276252713/appeal_2.png]'2nd ban in a month, git rekt'[/url] to which I showed that part of the stated reason for the appeal decision was wrong and that I wanted to know which rule I broke to deserve the ban. [url=https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/876836735630340217/1085707828532101241/appeal_3.png]'Dont ever talk to me or my son again'[/url]. No further comment on my part to keep my ticket privilege for my last ticket. The funny thing about this denied appeal is that there is another user who was banned 4 times [now 5] on the forum in the last month, and they were [url=https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/876836735630340217/1085766866628263976/unbanned_so_many_times.png]unbanned through legitimate appeals[/url]. This happens, support centers have different people with different tendencies except... hold-up... [url=https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/876836735630340217/1085726712362434580/double_standards_the.png]what if they were the same person[/url]??? And, no, every person I have talked to who tried to send in support tickets was answered by the same person, you can even look up their name on several Ark websites.

3) [url=https://media.discordapp.net/attachments/876836735630340217/1085721070885163048/image.png?ex=6595fb8b&is=6583868b&hm=cb014f61a4b4577e43174458553df84d1e2636c739030447192c3b0de562885e&=&format=webp&quality=lossless&width=833&height=702]Account suspended when I tried to resend the abuse request.[/url] Honestly, there was no point in even trying. Maybe I posted improperly, maybe I made a poorly delivered joke or two, but I did not do anything outside of average steam-user behavior and was exorcised completely from the community I gave a damn about. Again, permabanning instantly for first time offenders for a mild joke isn't just, permabanning users for quoting someone who isn't punished isn't just, and deleting all comments/posts someone made out of pure spite isn't just. 

Addendum: The whole 'generic name' and a 'few people use it' is bs. You can find several different websites with 1 person by that name that is associated with WC and in all their profiles it says 'WC support'. I would show their name but I am not out to start a witch hunt, only expose how insanely corrupt their system is.

My early thoughts on this game were positive. The premise is very interesting and the dinosaurs actually make you feel immersed like a survivor in a jungle trying to make their way in a pre-historic setting. My game ran poorly but I just assumed it was because my PC setup wasn't great at the time. As of upgrading my PC's specs, I fully expected this game to run better. The answer was no. 

I go back to this game after playing other, much better survival games. No Man's Sky was a surprising comeback. Valheim is just amazing and cheap. Project Zomboid is the best zombie survival game out there. ARK has great ideas, but fails to stick out with more potentially interesting mechanics and the game's studio seems more concerned about making money than fixing the horrendous number of bugs in the game, crappy UI, and abysmal server connection. Oh, official servers are gone? Well screw the players I guess.

Personally, I like it. But if you don't like taming stuff, defeating bosses (optional), story lines, getting killed a lot by players, or dinosaurs, you probably won't like this.
For one, if you're playing with at least one other person‚Äîfamily, friend, relative, etc.‚Äîyou can start wars or put them in your tribe.
2: Once you tame two opposite-gender dinosaurs, you can breed them infinitely as long as your breeding times are lowered. Nice thing for wars.
3: Most carnivores are OP. Tamed or not.
4: The water is very, very questionable in this game. And terrifying. There are a lot of creatures in it; be careful going into things that lead to the ocean (rivers, footpaws, etc.). As megalodons swim there most of the time, they are not the only deep creatures in this game. In the lake at footpaw (default pawn), there are piranhas: hostile, salmon shark (neutral, i think), etc.
5: Pretty buggy, the occasional disappearance of dinos every now and then has never happened to me within my 750 hours, but I've seen it happen to others.
6: This game isn't too grindy, apart from getting creatures, growing them, and the levels.
7: To take down ANY dinosaur quickly (other than titano and giga),¬† just hit them with 1‚Äì15 tranq arrows with a crossbow; they enhance the narco more!!

ARK: Survival Evolved transports players to a breathtaking world where survival reigns supreme amidst towering dinosaurs and untamed landscapes. The game's immersive sandbox environment challenges players to explore, build, tame creatures, and ultimately thrive in a world filled with both beauty and danger.

What sets ARK apart is its vast and diverse ecosystem. The game offers a richly detailed world with a wide array of dinosaurs and creatures to encounter, tame, and ride. The survival mechanics, including crafting, building bases, hunting, and taming creatures, create a deeply engaging experience that rewards resourcefulness and adaptation.

The game's multiplayer component fosters alliances and rivalries among players, leading to emergent gameplay experiences and epic battles. The sense of progression, from starting as a stranded survivor to establishing a thriving base and mastering powerful creatures, adds a compelling layer to the gameplay.

ARK's continuous updates and expansions showcase a commitment to evolving the game and keeping the experience fresh. Additionally, the modding community contributes to the game's longevity, offering a multitude of user-generated content that enhances and extends the gameplay.

For players seeking a thrilling survival experience set in a world where prehistoric creatures roam, ARK: Survival Evolved offers an immersive journey filled with discovery, adventure, and the thrill of mastering a wild and untamed environment.

[h1]This is my review after 61 hours of game play:[/h1]

A. [i]Survival game with a harsh learning curve. What doesn't kill you makes you stronger.[/i]

B. [i]There are options the player can choose to make the game easy to extremely difficult.[/i]

C. [i]Graphics are nice but somewhat dated.  But still it's beautiful and playable.[/i]

D. [i]Speaking from experience, as a beginner, it is very intimidating. [/i]

E. [i]I found that it's best played with others on PVE and/or PVP servers.  Choose your server wisely or start your own.[/i]

F.  [i]There is an active player base.[/i]

G. [i]Player base has declined over the years,  but, there are still a few partially working mods that a player can choose to use on Steam to help soften the learning curve.[/i]

H. [i]Each dino has a different use.[/i]

[u]BOTTOM LINE:[/u]

[b]There are a lot of content maps to choose from, so it should keep a player challenged to survive, adventure, harvest, craft, build, trap, kill  and tame wild pets/mounts to do a lot of their dirty work and/or mate to have better pets for many many many hours.

Enjoy[/b]

"ARK: Survival Evolved" is an engaging and immersive survival game with a unique twist of living alongside dinosaurs. Its vast, open-world environment filled with a wide range of prehistoric creatures offers both wonder and danger. The game excels in its crafting and base-building mechanics, allowing for creativity and strategic thinking. Taming dinosaurs adds an exciting and rewarding element to the gameplay. However, it can be quite challenging, especially for solo players, and the performance issues can be a drawback. Overall, ARK provides a thrilling survival experience, especially enjoyable in multiplayer mode.

I cannot fathom how a game like this could last this long and be developed for this long without ever iterating or improving on the actual game design, [b][i]EVER[/i][/b].

Every system in this game is like it was designed by a 9th grader and implemented by a 7th grader. The ONLY things going for this game are:
A) It has dinosaurs
B) It has base building

THAT'S IT.

Seriously. The only possible thing that makes this game fun rely 100% on having a community that's fun to play with, in spite of how dreadful every facet of the experience that Ark tries to serve to you is. Ark is never fun [i]because[/i] of the game mechanics. It's fun [i]in spite of[/i] the game mechanics.

The taming mechanics are absurdly unintuitive, not engaging in the least, and do not pass any metrics of good game design.

The level system and dinosaur stats have no rhyme or reason and seem arbitrary at best and deliberately useless at worst.

The spawning system has no purpose or reasoning behind it. Max level dinosaurs and alphas can spawn at the starting locations just as often as anywhere else, meaning there's both no reason to go anywhere outside of finding new dinos, and, critically, zero protections from getting overrun with a bad start. It was literally implemented as, "Hurp derp. dino_level = rand(1,130); spawnDino();"

Breeding is like it was just picked out of a hat at random and thrown together in 15 minutes and never touched since then.

The progression system and bosses have no bearing on one another and you can effectively play the entire game without ever looking at a boss and you'll have lost nothing of value. And what bosses you do choose to fight aren't interesting fights at all. They just stand there, smacking your inevitable horde of tames like two morons trading slaps until one side falls over.

In fact, that's literally all of combat in the game is standing face-to-face with another creature and slapping each other until one of you falls over. Sitting in the heaviest armor with the max HP and weapons is literally the most effective way to play the game.

None of the game's fundamental mechanics have any cohesion. They're all completely separated and divorced from one another on all levels logically and functionally. Each independent system has as much iteration and design potential thrown into it that a literal child would.

This game, PixArk, and now "Survival Ascended", all had the potential to be great games, but instead, the absolutely pathetic studio designers would rather focus on shameless cash grabs relying on pretty graphics to fool you into believing the game is worth anything, instead of spending the same amount of effort hiring someone who actually knows how to make games fun and who might actually be able to turn this colossal shitstorm of high-def assets into a functional gaming experience that doesn't need to rely on a laundry list of mods to make 1) work, 2) performant, and 3) fun.

A company that can make as much money as Studio Wildcard and still have this ass of gameplay in their game is honestly unfathomable in game development. It's lead by a bunch of sociopaths with zero care for actually making a game and who want to find as many ways of peddling the same dross over and over again to the masses driven by nostalgia for a game that never existed.

You took advantage of a community for a decade. A community that prayed that you would take your cobbled-together product with infinite potential and polish it into the game they believed it could be. But they were duped. Every last one of us. Once you got your money and 15 minutes of fame, you jacked the price of your shitty alpha test to triple and you genuinely thought you deserved it and never bothered to finish it.

I mean, why would you? The community was already lapping your piss off the floor. Why actually bother to make the game good if you can just exploit the hype instead? You never have to do any real work and you make the same amount of money.

Yeah, fuck you, Studio Wildcard. Fuck this dogshit ass game that we tried so hard to enjoy in spite of your presence. Fuck Survival Ascended and fuck Ark 2. It's gonna be the exact same game as this. Dogshit. You will fix nothing. You will serve slop and you will demand the masses enjoy it because you have actually, unironically, drank your own kool-aid and you believe you are God's gift to game development. You fucking suck at developing video games and until that changes, this review will stand.

Eat shit.

I don't know why, but i just love this game. Even though all playthroughs start with you getting mauled by Alpha Raptor, it still has that charm that is so difficult to describe that I might even call it impossible to describe. However, there's always a catch, and the catch in this game is all the DLCs that came after Aberation pushed on TEK stuff, which i really hate. I want to tame some dinos with a bow and arrow, not fly around like drunk iron man. It especially gets worse in both Genesis parts, where developers for some reason thought it'd be a good idea to add missions that you need to grind day and night to access the final boss, and worst of all, the hexagon shop, where you can buy most of the top gear, element, top-tier saddles all for the cost of playing a couple of piss-easy missions like dodo basketball in a survival game. However, if we ignore the Genesis DLCs, the game is brilliant. Don't expect the good story, though; the deeper you look, the more crappy and lefty it'll become. All things considered, a great game that is more addictive than crack cocaine.

This game is really fun but not for the faint of heart, the expression "Getting ARKed" doesn't exist for nothing. This game will chew you up and spit you out so you got to take it. But the joy of getting a base established, taming a dino, and beating your first boss (Even though i haven't beaten a boss personally) Makes all the frustration worth it. If you enjoy playing other hard survival games like Terraria, ARK won't be so hard. If your going to play on a server (There won't be any official servers ever since ASA came out) I don't suggest playing on a PVP server because there super difficult and cut throat. If you need any help i suggest watching guides on youtube, (i personally suggest Pterafire's survival handbook) I hope this review helped you start playing a great game.

Now that Ark: Survival Ascended is out, the "old" game is being kept alive by people running their own servers. This has lead to some of the most fun interaction and gaming I've had on Ark in YEARS. If you haven't, buy this when it's on crazy Steam sale and then funnel a donation or two to the community you find in searching the alt servers. Absolutely worth doing.

I have played for around 1636 hours, and 1600 of those were single player. 
This is one of the coolest survival games ever.
The settings was:
Player resistance -> 3 hard or 4 expert (Don't get bitten)
Player damage -> 3 
Don't! use singleplayer settings

From the menu "Advance"
"Wild dino stats per level" -> Set health and damage to 2.5.
From "Tamed dinos stats per level" and down: Add per level, Affinty
Set all Health and dmg stats to 0.01 ( No more ez OP dino mode. Your tamed rex level 50 can now die to a level 80 if it got bad stats.)  

Show floating damage text - Yes

Everything else was default.

Mods: 
Resource stacks
Dino hunger meter
Immersive Taming -> But remove all "combat taming" from the process. 

Now make a Youtube video of you completing the boss fights.! 
Happy fighting 

10/10

As cool and fun as this game is, I cannot recommend it for two reasons. For one, it suffers from the same issue as every survival game on Steam: A buggy mess that will always feel like an early access game, at least the other survival games are honest enough to keep the early access label for the decade they've been out. The other reason is the fact that this game takes up 330 GB of space installed (180 if you only install the base map.) That is entirely too much space taken up for me to justify keeping it installed to play every once in awhile, unless I really want to sink a hundred hours into a save or something, I won't reinstall it. The developers really need to work on compressing all of this stuff down, like idk why it takes double the space if you install a few more maps, or why you need to take up so much in the first place but it is retarded; I have played games with far more content that are a tenth of the space or less that this takes up.

edit:
Ark: Survival Evolved - A Magnum Opus in Gaming Excellence
In the vast landscape of video games, where titles compete for attention and player loyalty, one game stands out as a true titan - "Ark: Survival Evolved." Developed by Studio Wildcard and released in 2015, Ark has managed to captivate the gaming community with its unique blend of survival elements, open-world exploration, and innovative gameplay mechanics. This essay explores the reasons why Ark: Survival Evolved can be considered the best game of all time. Immersive Open-World Experience:
At the heart of Ark's brilliance lies its sprawling, visually stunning open-world environment. The game transports players to the mysterious and dangerous island of ARK, teeming with prehistoric creatures and lush landscapes. The attention to detail in crafting this world is unparalleled, offering a visually immersive experience that rivals even the most cinematic games. The diversity of ecosystems, from dense jungles to frigid tundras, adds to the sense of adventure and discovery. Every corner of the island holds secrets, resources, and challenges, encouraging players to explore and engage with the environment actively. This open-world design fosters a sense of wonder and excitement, making Ark a game where every playthrough feels like a unique adventure. Dynamic and Realistic Ecosystem:
One of Ark's standout features is its dynamic ecosystem, where players must contend not only with other human survivors but also with a variety of AI-controlled creatures. The realism and attention to detail in the behavior of these creatures elevate Ark above its peers. The day-and-night cycle, weather patterns, and the predatory instincts of the dinosaurs contribute to a living, breathing world. Survivors must learn to adapt to the behaviors of different species, creating a sense of tension and excitement. Whether it's taming a massive T-Rex, avoiding a pack of raptors, or navigating the skies on a flying mount, every encounter feels like a unique challenge. This dynamic ecosystem adds an extra layer of depth to the gameplay, making Ark an ever-evolving experience that keeps players on their toes. Innovative Taming and Breeding Mechanics:
Ark: Survival Evolved introduces a revolutionary taming and breeding system that sets it apart from other survival games. Players can tame a wide array of dinosaurs and other creatures, turning them into loyal companions, mounts, or even powerful allies in battle. The process of taming involves everything from strategic planning and resource management to understanding the unique preferences of each species. The breeding mechanic takes the realism a step further, allowing players to raise and genetically modify their creatures. This adds a compelling layer of depth to the game, as players can invest time and effort into creating stronger, more resilient generations of creatures. The emotional connection that forms between players and their tamed creatures enhances the overall gaming experience, making Ark a truly memorable and personal journey. Complex Crafting and Building System:
Ark's crafting and building system is a masterpiece of complexity and creativity. From simple tools to elaborate fortresses, players can craft a vast array of items using resources gathered from the environment. The depth of the crafting system encourages strategic planning and resource management, adding an intellectual challenge to the game. The building mechanics allow players to construct intricate bases that serve both practical and aesthetic purposes. Whether building a fortress to fend off hostile players or creating a tranquil haven in the wilderness, the possibilities are limited only by the player's imagination. The sense of accomplishment derived from constructing a well-designed and functional base is unparalleled, creating a strong sense of ownership and pride. Multiplayer Dynamics and Community Interaction:
Ark's multiplayer dynamics are a crucial aspect of its appeal. The game supports both player-vs-environment (PvE) and player-vs-player (PvP) modes, offering diverse experiences to suit different playstyles. In PvP, the competitive nature of surviving against both the environment and other players adds a thrilling edge to the game. The constant threat of raids and the need for strategic alliances create a dynamic social environment.
On PvE servers, players can collaborate to overcome the challenges of the island without the constant threat of hostile players. The sense of community that emerges on these servers fosters cooperation, teamwork, and the sharing of knowledge. This communal aspect adds longevity to the game, as players form alliances, trade resources, and engage in large-scale cooperative ventures. Regular Content Updates and Support:
Ark: Survival Evolved has demonstrated a commitment to its player base through consistent and substantial content updates. Studio Wildcard's dedication to refining and expanding the game has kept players engaged over the years. New maps, creatures, and features are regularly introduced, ensuring that the game remains fresh and exciting. The developers actively listen to player feedback and address issues promptly, creating a symbiotic relationship with the community. This ongoing support not only enhances the overall gaming experience but also demonstrates a level of care and dedication that is rare in the gaming industry. In the vast and diverse landscape of video games, Ark: Survival Evolved stands out as a testament to the potential of the medium. Its immersive open-world, dynamic ecosystem, innovative mechanics, complex crafting system, multiplayer dynamics, and consistent updates collectively contribute to its status as a game of unparalleled excellence. Ark has not only redefined the survival genre but has also created a gaming experience that transcends the boundaries of traditional gameplay. As players continue to explore the mysteries of the ARK, it becomes increasingly clear that Ark: Survival Evolved has secured its place as one of the greatest games of all time.

I wanted to like this game, but the reality is otherwise. 

- There are too many visual bugs (mostly reflections)
- The brightness is awful (I literally can't do anything at night cause I don't see anything)
- The building aspect is also poor (I hate that after 30 seconds I can not get all my resources back)
- Temperature bug (in some locations temperature is from 30 to -30 in a few steps from each other)
- Dino's poor obstacle avoidance (When Dino is following you it could stick everywhere).
- Light problem (When you a looking to the side from where the is sun, you will see only the white light and no more, for me it happened when I was looking from the forest to the beach)

I was trying to play as it was created by the author. But it looks more like torture, not enjoyment. So the only way to play ARK is to download mods that will fix every annoying problem.

P.S.

Take this review with a grain of salt since I've only been able to play Ark for nearly 20 hours.  Before I even delve into the gameplay, let me share with you the straw that broke the camel's back - the sheer amount of storage space that this game consumes.  Don't let the download screen fool you - this game consumes well over 100GB of storage space when extracted.  Even worse, each new update adds 10+ GBs of content.  With unimpressive visuals, it's actually insane that Ark requires this much space.  The textures are nothing to write home about and the vistas in the starting area were far from postcard-worthy.  Regardless, I had attempted to play this game after some time away, when the latest update completely filled my download cache and destination drive.  Even after clearing out my unplayed games, it was still too big to fit in either drive.  It was this point, after the latest update pushed my drive to its limit, that I uninstalled.

Secondly, the game is optimized so poorly that my 1080TI was struggling to run it on High settings.  The game does NOT look good enough to warrant my PC raising the temp of my entire apartment complex by 10 degrees.  It is actually ridiculous how much of a lack of concern the devs have with your ability to run this game.  Once they sell it to you with a shiny wrapper and the promise of having the Jurassic aged army of your dreams, you're practically dead to them.  Mission accomplished.
  
But none of that is really my main gripe.  You could skirt past these nitpicks for sure.  But no, my real issue is the gameplay, which, for any interactive experience I engage in, is most important.  First of all, I'm not sure how this game gets away with forcing the player to spend so much time performing mundane tasks only to subsequently punish the player with the plethora of bugs and RNG littered throughout the game.  Did you just spend several hours obtaining that trike you wanted?  Have a small army of gargantuan lizards at your command?  Trained each dino to be stronger and faster than your average plebeian?  Great!  Now watch as a few untimely spawns result in an aerial raid that swoops in and leaves your army and co-op partners in shambles!

To put it in perspective, during my first experience playing this game with some friends, the following events transpired:

* Crafted some decent weapons and a reasonable cache of supplies
* Tamed some low level dinos
* Tamed some tankier mid-level dinos
* Built a 2 story base of operations atop a fortified hill
* Built the majority of a wall around our base
* Assembled armor of decent quality and mid tier ranged weaponry

This equated to about... 10+ hours of work for me alone.  And most of it was coordinated by my tribe mates while I had already logged off for the night.  Note that I use the word "work" with FULL intention - all of these tasks were a slog and did not hold any innate entertainment value.  One of my least favorite of said chores was dino taming, which required that we babysit the dinos we wished to subdue while we periodically force feed them berrires/meats.  

Once our work had been completed, we could finally start getting into the groove and have a little fun exploring.  We had dinos to ride and places to be.  Our base was on the peak of a hill overlooking the landscape.  It was reasonably well fortified.  We had a pretty darn good foundation and were ready to set out... until a T-Rex-lookin' rage lizard that spawned meters away from our camp decided that it hated our tribe and everything it stood for.  A few grueling minutes and several futile deaths later, the damage was done.  Might as well have slapped a game over sign on the screen right then and there. 

So what was the damage tally exactly?  Most of us permanently lost our gear because we couldn't find it amidst the field of slaughter.  One player's gear clipped through the terrain, lost to the world.  All of our dinos, sans one tiny little guy who actually heeded our orders to stay within the base walls, were slaughtered mercilessly.  The demon spawn dino had left its mark all over the battlefield in the form of feces strewn with the DNA of our lost reptilian brethren.  Needless to say, that was a hard stop to the barely existent enjoyment elicited by this game.

I've tried to get started in this game twice since then, and have had similar experiences both times, though not nearly at the same tragic scale.  I think I can safely say that if you are the sort of person who appreciates hoarding your money for years only to have some lowlife dip steal your identity and make off with the lot of it, you would absolutely love this game!  I for one, in my barely sane mind, do not.  

To be fair, perhaps the hardcore survival game enthusiast would appreciate how uncannily rough this game is.  Though the lack of polish and care would grate on even the most avid of survival fans.  I thought I was included in their ranks, but clearly, after playing Ark, I discovered the limits of what I could feasibly survive.  Godspeed to all those who long for Ark's unique brand of suffering.  

P.S. In the spirit of fairness, yes, you can scale down some the more grindy elements in the game if you start your own server.  Did it matter that much when we tried it?  Not really.  Just meant that our inevitable loss hurt that much less when our tragic fate came to fruition.  But it was still time wasted, no matter how you slice it.  With that said, cheers to you, Ark - a complete waste of (nearly) 20 hours of my life.

I bought and played this game a few months after the Alpha became publicly playable.

ARK has provided me thousands hours of entertainment.  At first, I started playing single player offline pve with a group of local buddies. Fantastic. Awesome game. Tons of dinos to choose from, great graphics(great sense of danger in the wild if you're playing on normal or harder settings and it requires effort to stay safe and survive). Lots of items and exciting game mechanics. 

After a good few weeks of offline fun, we travelled online(TBH Offline multiplayer was so fun I forgot online existed). However, I really felt like official servers already were "Spoiled" in a way. Theyre already super populated, every viable spot for a base or to farm resources is just inaccessible to you as a low level noob to the server because it's 'owned' by alpha tribes. Huge tribes are already established and they are not very outside player friendly. You either join them and be forced to play the game by their rules, or basically get spawn camped/imprisoned indefinitely. 

So then we decided to play on some private servers that seemed better governed. After a few tries, we quickly learned private servers aren't much better as servers owners usually just spawn in cool dinos and items for themselves and people close to them, making it seem pointless to actually go out and tame anything to compete, besides the fact it all kind of has the same 'Everybodys already been here and done that' feel to it. A few private servers we tried even had admins who would spawn in items/dinos for real $. Pay to win isn't my cup of tea. 

At this point my friends stopped playing, but I was dedicated and when I finally found what seemed like a friendly, decent PVE server, I enjoyed building up a base and a mini army over the course of a few weeks, only for it to be completely destroyed one morning upon logging in because somebody looted my base, let my dinos out, and my dinos killed some neighboring tribes dinos. Well, this tribe happened to be close to the admin and the admin literally just wiped our base because of something that happened while I was offline and had nothing to do with me. They just referenced the tribe log with my dinos and didn't care about my progress. After that I decided to play offline forever after. 

The game has a lot of small bugs but I personally have never had any huge issues that didn't stem solely from the fact it's UE4

Playing offline PVE is where almost all my gameplay time comes from, after my online experience. I treat this game as a solely offline hardcore survival game, with a bunch of mods from the workshop and a little bit of self-roleplay. I just couldn't find any joy in the online play but I can understand those that do.

[h1]Overview[/h1]
I heard this game long time ago since some youtubers played it and we can eat our own Poop. I wanted it.

I saw it on steam sale one time and happen to have money left from last game I bought so why not (and regret it later since epic make this game free). Turn out the thing that is missing from vanilla minecraft, the forest, etc games that contains survival and exploration is here. Sadly I dont have many friends like survival genre and dinosaur lol. So I play this game alone to this day.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
+ Combined minecraft, the forest, etc. Those survival games I liked so much.
+ A mysterious story scattered on the island or any map you played. Make me curious to explore and truly progressing the game with boss battles.
+ Dinosaur mixed with modern alien like tech that doesnt feel too out of place actually.
+ Can make my own troops and Zoos lol, buldings is ok thing yif you know what you doing since the tutorial isn't clearly teach you how to assemble things than create material for it.
+ Game element is good and can be tweaked or nerfed as I like, giving much freedom to shape the game to what I like. Make sure you do it especially if playing with less than 4 people or alone.
+ Multiplayer can be fun. But again if you know how it works tho since no official support to make your own private game lobby/server.
+ Mod support, can fix many of the game QOL issues or bad takes of the game play devs did.
+ Eat your own poo/dino poop and getting sick. Perfection.
+ Dino variant even in the island map (1st base game map) is so many, every biome is different and make me more diligent to explore and tame. And the map is beautiful.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- Size of the game is HUGE (I don't have big storage) base game already reach almost 110GB!! not mention expansion packs. Idk if I ever want to buy the expansion due to its sizes. Why not optimizing size of this game? And look they remasters the game now, with twice the size and twice the bug apparently.
- The performance of the game is horribly optimized, lags here and there. The game is so demanding and somehow demand RTX 4090 performance and still have issues. While the game itself look pretty it wasn't that amazing to require this much taxing performances. RDR2 is looking more amazing and I can run it in medium and it looks amazing with no issues. And they proceed to their next sequel somehow lol.
- The grinding when playing single player is ungodly. If you not tweak the world settings for single player, you will be punished severely playing alone with vanilla settings. Make sure you tinker with it.
- A tiny bit of clipping and glitch can save you or break your game. I mean break your game so you need to restart the whole save.
- Flying too high regards you out of bounds and resulting player dead, make your items disappears and sometimes your Dino just stuck in the air, making you need to find other argentavish, pterodactyl, etc for just call back your Dino. There's a mod to that since this is the one of most annoying thing in this game really.
- When you died or left your Dino in someplace you forgot, well goodbye. Thank god there's a mod for that problems. Annoying really.
- Idk but flying is so slow lol. There's a settings for it but why the vanilla setting so bad?? Make sure to tune it up especially playing alone.
- Weapon variance is very limited, but hey there's a mod to that. The jump from stone age to sci-fi is weird since the more modern you got the smaller things you can make.
- Some resources its really hard to farm/grind alone in base settings especially playing alone, but there's a settings for that and mods to help you.
- Mechanics of plumbing is questionable and logic defying, so for first timers its really hard to getting hang of it if not online guides helps you. (At least for me)
- Playing private multiplayer with friends is complex to settings, there's no options in main game how to configure this. You forced to use 3rd party software such as epidemic, tunggle, etc. that I find too complicated and confusing. There's a easier way to play with "Tethering" but you can explore game too far from each other or the game will force teleport you to host which is sucks really...
- ONLY play with FRIENDS for multiplayer. The public servers monopolized by "Alpha Tribes" that only griefing, raids newer players, etc. The public multiplayer filled with toxic, slavery, bully, etc to new players joining. Also idk how the hell the main server level cap/difficulty is ungodly, I cant even kill regular dodo at lvl 1 wtf? Completely ruin the game for new players. This is why i prefer single player or with friends only.
[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Well the game living its name in steam quick review format as one category of the most taxing performance, bug ridden, unstable, glitchy, etc. But actually its not that bad for a game if they actually take times to polish it and optimized the textures. But instead they moving on with "remasters" since they seem to running out of budget for Ark 2 bcs they wasted it so much at marketing and weird projects outside the game than actually finishing this game or making the sequels. Reminds me a lot of Yahoo collapse. I don't recommend this game by this point anymore since major issues wont be updated anyway and we all know what kind of Devs we see here.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poaceae

Poaceae (/po äÀàe…™sia…™, -siÀêiÀê/) or Gramineae (/…°r…ôÀàm…™nia…™/) is a large and nearly ubiquitous family of monocotyledonous flowering plants commonly known as grasses. It includes the cereal grasses, bamboos and the grasses of natural grassland and species cultivated in lawns and pasture. The latter are commonly referred to collectively as grass.

With around 780 genera and around 12,000 species,[4] the Poaceae is the fifth-largest plant family, following the Asteraceae, Orchidaceae, Fabaceae and Rubiaceae.[5]

The Poaceae are the most economically important plant family, providing staple foods from domesticated cereal crops such as maize, wheat, rice, barley, and millet as well as feed for meat-producing animals. They provide, through direct human consumption, just over one-half (51%) of all dietary energy; rice provides 20%,[6] wheat supplies 20%, maize (corn) 5.5%, and other grains 6%[citation needed]. Some members of the Poaceae are used as building materials (bamboo, thatch, and straw); others can provide a source of biofuel, primarily via the conversion of maize to ethanol.

Grasses have stems that are hollow except at the nodes and narrow alternate leaves borne in two ranks. The lower part of each leaf encloses the stem, forming a leaf-sheath. The leaf grows from the base of the blade, an adaptation allowing it to cope with frequent grazing.

Grasslands such as savannah and prairie where grasses are dominant are estimated to constitute 40.5% of the land area of the Earth, excluding Greenland and Antarctica.[7] Grasses are also an important part of the vegetation in many other habitats, including wetlands, forests and tundra.

Though they are commonly called "grasses", groups such as the seagrasses, rushes and sedges fall outside this family. The rushes and sedges are related to the Poaceae, being members of the order Poales, but the seagrasses are members of order Alismatales. However, all of them belong to the monocot group of plants.

[h1]Ark as single player experience[/h1]
I'm a huge dino fan and didn't need the trappings of PvP and tribes, and wanted to share my perspective having focused on single player.

My saved game, nearly a hundred hours in, was corrupted and lost. Several of my dinos have, on two seperate occasions, fallen through the world to an irretrievable purgatory at the bottom of the map. There have been a number of occasions where I have cursed my luck and the RNG gods. But then...

I ride through the jungle on my Iguanodon, looking for adventure...
Or I sail up the river, a dinosaur as my lone companion on a raft...
Or I simply walk under my T-Rex, and I grin.

The game world is gorgeous, and you can tame and then ride dinosaurs. So few games offer such an experience, and that's why I'll keep coming back, bugs and all.

~~~
Updated review (Nov. 2020)

The game continues to innovate entertain. With new dinos and updates to existing ones, there's always something new to discover. The mod scene continues to be innovative... anytime I get frustrated with the Single Player experience, I find a mod that remedies the problem.

EDIT: I now no longer recommend buying ASA or ASE. They somehow made cheating, exploits, etc. even worse than they were on ASE.

For everyone seeing the recent negative reviews, let me give you a better picture of the situation (know that I'm giving it a bad review, but only this version, NOT the upgraded version which I DO RECOMMEND buying when allowed):

Wildcard has decided to "remaster" the game in Unreal Engine 5, adding other features, and improving things. Their port of Unreal Engine 4 is bad, and the game needed it. Because of this they are also getting rid of the Ark 1 servers entirely (other than unofficial servers obviously), in favor of the new and improved game upon being released.

While you see people complaining about this, realize that on OFFICIAL SERVERS as it stands, the vast MAJORITY of people are cheating. A quick Youtube search will show you just how bad and blatant it is. Something NEEDED TO BE DONE to solve this issue, because it is near unplayable for legitimate players with thousands of hours of experience, much less NEW PLAYERS who will have exactly 0% chance to enjoy the game.

The current state of their Official servers is NOT sustainable for years to come (which they planned to still support the servers), under the current load. Bringing in new people doesn't work under these conditions.

Originally it was supposed to be a free upgrade, but upon realizing it's not that easy to just make backwards compatible, along with everything else said, and the amount of work needed to be put into it, they are opting to charge $50, for BOTH the UPGRADED UE5, AND Ark 2 (pre order bundle).

This means if you do buy, you're basically buying each game for $25. The only major issue is they are charging an extra $40 for all of the expansions.

My personal suggestion for the next game if you're interested is buy it. You'll easily get your moneys worth out of it, get another game, and IF everything is better as it should be (including less cheaters based off the changes), then buying the DLC going forward is worth it.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I've played ARK: Survival Evolved since it's pre-release and it's a great game in so many ways, to briefly sum it up - not only are the graphics awesome, there is also a great progression system in the game which allows you to learn new engrams / skills, craft items, weapons and build so many different things to help your battle with survival. You can explore caves, oceans, forests, swamps, mountains and much more and also tame creatures to help you throughout the game, the changes in weather vary depending on where in the world you go, which makes it very fun and challenging. There is a good Tribe system which is great for playing with friends / group / clan members and I always enjoyed the different events the game offered such as Fear Evolved and Winter Wonderland. The game also offers single player mode and you can play competitive PvP in Multiplayer, or simply against the environment in PvE depending on your preference. If you like survival games with a difference, and the ability to progress and take on new challenges then I would definitely recommend this game, ARK: Survival Evolved is the best survival game I have played to date. 

The DLC expansions are all worth it and have their own unique features and characteristics, bringing even more to the story and the journey for the explorer.

- Played since pre-release in 2015 and I've seen all the new content come in over the years, and I'm still playing now at the time of this update (2021)!

- I'm still playing this at the end of 2023. I've enjoyed the story that's been brought to the game over the last several years and the evolution of the characters and dialogue. The added voice overs are a great addition and give the story an extra spark of life. All the DLC's are unique and incredibly detailed and the latest creatures keep making things interesting :)

It's hard to recommend this, it can be fun but you will find a lot of bs along the way.
To give you an example there is a reload bug in the game with certain weapons like the bow where the reload animation will play, and all visuals will point to you having reloaded except you cannot shoot.
Only when you look at the hotbar do you see it somehow didn't actually reload.

Now I would say this is a pretty game breaking bug, but at the very least you can't argue it's incredibly annoying.
The kicker here is that there are posts going back 6 years of this bug being reported by the community, and Wildcard still hasn't fixed it.

There are more relatively small but annoying bugs like these, for example it's also far too common that you will hit something with sound, visuals etc all confirming but it will do absolutely nothing.
A hit in the head will count as a body shot and vice versa.
Opening the server browser on default filters freezes your game as it collects info of 5000+ servers on the UI thread.
Single player has worse performance than running a dedicated server /on the same machine/.

This along with the reskin of ARK that is Atlas, and now the ARK in a new jacket that is ARK: Survival Ascended, leaves me with very, very little trust and respect for the developers.

That all said, if you collect some friends, some mods, and are techie enough to setup and debug a server (or just pay for one) you can still have a good time with it.
That however is not enough for me to be able to recommend buying the game.
The ability to build, to die and to laugh with friends, enemies and even fri-enemies is fun.  Interacting with dinos, learning to tame, breed and just go out and rescue makes it a lot of fun to play.

"Ark: Survival Evolved" is a rollercoaster of survival insanity that has kept me hooked from the get-go. Kudos to Studio Wildcard for creating a game that's as challenging as it is captivating.

The scale of this game is mind-blowing. The diverse landscapes, from lush jungles to icy peaks, and the attention to detail in the creatures make exploring the map a constant adventure. There's a genuine sense of awe when you come face to face with a towering dinosaur or discover a hidden oasis.

Survival is the name of the game, and "Ark" nails it. Starting from scratch on a mysterious island, you're thrown into a world where every resource matters. Crafting tools, building a shelter, and taming dinosaurs for companionship or battle‚Äîit's a relentless but rewarding cycle.

The multiplayer aspect is where "Ark" really shines. Forming tribes and engaging in epic battles or cooperative building projects with other players adds a whole new layer to the experience. The stories that emerge from these interactions make each server feel alive.

Now, let's talk about the not-so-glamorous side. Optimization can be a bit of a headache. The game looks gorgeous, but performance issues on certain systems can be a drawback. It's a small price to pay for the breathtaking visuals, but it's worth noting.

And yes, the learning curve is steep. "Ark" doesn't hold your hand, and survival can be brutal. But trust me, the satisfaction of building a thriving base and taming powerful creatures makes the struggle worthwhile.

In a nutshell, "Ark: Survival Evolved" is a crazy, challenging, and utterly addictive survival experience. The massive world, the thrill of taming dinosaurs, and the dynamic multiplayer interactions make it a must-play. Sure, there are some performance hiccups and a tough learning curve, but the sheer depth and excitement of the gameplay make it an adventure worth diving into.

*Update*
Y'know, I've put nearly 5k hours into this game. There's a reason for that. It's a good game. It's a very fun and enjoyable game. Would I recommend it? Yes. Very Yes. It's fun and can be a fantastic way to sink many hours into.
It can be quite the labour of love this game. It can take a while to get use to at the beginning. You will die, for many many reason. You were attacked by a dilo. 
You were attacked by a rex. 
You couldn't find a water source. 
You fell off a rock that was higher than expected. 
You were collecting fiber and accidentally hit the melee button so you punched a bronto's big toe and it got angry and smashed you in the face with its tail, which in itself didn't kill you, but knocked you far enough that you bounced off a cliff and fell to your death. Ah well, start collecting that thatch for you house again. But if you give this game the time, it can be very rewarding. The feeling of riding around on a giga and stomping down trees or munching anything in one bite is an amazing feeling when you think about the fact that a dino 1/5 your size kept stealing your berries a while ago on the beach. Damn you pegos!

I know I have been rather critical of the devs and while they are firm on their decision to not give customer support to legacy servers it doesn't seem to matter too much anymore. Many of the issues seem to be resolved as they find them, or at least a work around is deployed while they investigate them. With the use of the discord to reach out to many more players and customers it seems like Wild Card are making a much bigger effort to really get involved with their players and receive feedback. It's really encouraging and makes this game much more worth while. 
If you're looking for a game that will consume almost all of your free time but this isn't a problem for you, this is the game you need. Probably one of the best survival games out there.

*Update* 
I have played this game for over 2000 hours more since I wrote the above review. 
Do I recommend it? The game, yes I do, I do recommend it. The developer? Well, I'm not sure. They seem to enjoy adding new content and much of the new content is actually fun. The new maps are cool and the devs seem to be actually semi interested in encouraging mods.
However, there are some game breaking bugs that the devs seem to horrifically struggle to fix,  reporting in there weekly update blog that this is an 'ongoing issue being addressed' but never actually seems to be sorted.
Oh and they also still are giving the finger to the  players on their legacy servers. "Thanks for helping us improve the game to official release, oh and gl, you're on your own, oh you have this game breaking problem that could potentially ruin your entire game so far? Yeaaaa, nahhhhh....."

I have had a great deal of fun in this game. Over 700 hours of fun at the time of this review. The idea behind the game is brilliant and it had the potential to be an absolutely awesome long term project, but unfortunately I have come to realise this will not happen. Multiple bugs that remain for extended periods of time despite patches claiming to have fixed them. The patches themselves are big, sometimes in the multi gigabyte range and almost daily. 
However, the biggest problem is that the devs do not seem to care about the customers. Upon launch it was announced that the 'legacy' servers, the servers that existed during their beta testing time would have all customer support axed from them. That was a huge "screw you" to the bulk of their customer base. Because with the price increasing 4 fold I don't think they will be getting a massive increase in customers any time soon. 
Prior to that, any tickets I did send in were responded with "We are sorry but our customer service team is unable to assist you with this issue. Below is a link to the forums that may have details on how others solved this or a similar problem..."

Because of the coding issues and the lack of customer consideration I will not recommend this game. If you enjoy survival games with dinosaurs and such then go for, but don't expect anyone at Wildcard to help you if something goes wrong, you're out of luck there.

[h2]dont read or watch anything people say about this game or company there all lying and you will get lots of spoilers and make you play the wrong way even most reviews will be spoiling and tutorials or almost any youtube video except this one[/h2]
[h2]this review is objective all im doing is laying out the facts if i got something wrong tell me[/h2]
[h2]about[/h2] a story driven pve sci fi rpg about a mysterious island and you must find the mystery of the island and escape 
[h2]content[/h2] unbelievable amount  100s of hours of content and you can replay countless times because each time you play will be completely different a long story lots of areas to explore so many items(over 1000) and so many enemies(over 100 not counting bosses)
[h2]story[/h2]  ultra story driven and lots of detail and they explain everything every gameplay mechanic and every part of story and no plot holes and no annoying exposition it lets you play in and see the story for your own eyes they explain things like inventory with story and lots of lore 
[h2]multiplayer[/h2] you can play single player local online multiplayer mmo up to 100 players in 1 server 
[h2]freedom[/h2] unbelievable amount you can host your own server and customize 100s of rules and you have 100s of commands and you even have mods 
[h2]uniqueness[/h2] very unique most of the island is like real life except the obilisks which add a ton of uniqueness later game parts are very unique and you have super unique high tech 
[h2]glitches[/h2] the least bugs ive ever seen in a game after 100s of hours all you will find will be a minor visual bug like a flash on your screen for 0.05 seconds 
[h2]optimiztion[/h2] very the game runs fine at max graphics with a decent computer and its very complex 
[h2]graphics[/h2] good graphics level for most things is fine but some parts like water effects are bad but lots of ambiance
[h2]physics[/h2] good physics like momentum based fall damage or tek momentum physics and slightly broken but advanced ragdoll physics and dropped item physics
[h2]immersion[/h2] very immersive very story driven good graphics and ambiance such a small amount of bugs and lag and great ai and ui
[h2]ai[/h2] very advanced best ive ever seen creatures can form pacts some can send scouts and some fight eachother and some eat in the wild and they run when they about to die herbivores will actually eat plants when wild 
[h2]variety[/h2] lots you will never grind as long as you dont tame a lot and you dont die a lot lots of different tiers with lots of different weapons and lots of enemy types and they vary a lot even if there the same type lots of different areas 
[h2]skill[/h2] very skill based your reaction speeds aim perception will be stressed heavily and you will need massive amounts of quick thinking and strategy 
[h2]devs[/h2] unbelievable good best ive ever seen they interact very well they respond on all sorts of social media and they constantly talk about whats going on via community crunches they do yearly streams and donate to childrens hospitals ive even had a dev respond to me when no one in the community would and modding contests and official mods and they do much more great things  
[h2]other[/h2] dont get mods they cause lots of bugs and lag you can loss lots and its very very hard and its very thrilling because of it this is by far the most toxic community on earth i do not recommend official servers there not bad but there not the best way to play

Why ARK: Survival Evolved is the worst game in the world.

General issues:
Have you ever wondered how good your PC is? Well for a small investment of $65 AUD and a small investment of $45 AUD for each subsequent DLC which allow you to play the game properly, you can now benchmark your system. 
Step 0: Download Ark + DLCs (optional but not really) on an SSD (optional but not really) which will cost you approximately 3 business days and 650 gigabytes 
Step 1: click on servers. 
Step 2: join an official island server. 
Step 3: navigate your way to within a 50km range of Ice Cave. 
Step 4: if you get above 15fps, your PC is well suited to run ark, and you probably spent too much money on it. 
If you bought ARK for an immersive experience combined with a hardcore PVP experience, you have been lied to and should prepare to get shafted as the devs are f*cking braindead. Somehow managing to create neither, and through sheer ret@rdation created a game which crashes due to being open, and naturally has the worst desync possible due to all server hosting performed on a $30 toaster. If your PC cost <$4000 to assemble or you use an alienware assembled PC, do not expect to be able to play this game on >20 fps with constant stutters on lowest graphics, overclocking, and INI enabled. The minimum requirements on the ark store page are described as: NVIDIA GTX 670 , Intel I5, and 8gb ram, but they are lying to you and you will not actually get past the steam library, let alone reach the game settings, which is necessary to mute 'main menu music' before it causes irreparable ear damage to all who wish to launch the game. Hence, it is recommended to place your headphones outside, surrounded by pillows, with all doors and windows shut before attempting to open ark for the first time, and after any subsequent redownloads following the clearing of ssd space necessary to download other games. If all these obstacles are overcome and your game hours accidently exceeded 2 hours, you will then proceed to either Official or Unofficial where your will commence your rapid loss of braincells.

Official:
After spending >1700 hours playing this abomination which some may call a game, i can safely say that the official ark experience is comparable to running a marathon on legos. The sheer inability to play the game due to an agglomeration of trash servers which constantly lag and crash, obvious cheaters which don't get punished because the entire ark team are composed of pay check stealers, and servers which don't wipe, completely disable the average human from being able to waste enough braincells on this game to progress past stone hatchet. As an Australian player, it is difficult to find servers at all, let alone servers which function, have players, have less than 50% of the pop as cheaters, and have <300 ping which would enable us to shoot arrows out of a crossbow without having arrows frequently stuck in the chamber. Due to a lack of server wipes on ark official, it has become quite challenging to build a base or pvp for most players, and whilst the 20 remaining tryhard oce players no life this game for an eternal ego contest, blowing through stone bases with 2k dura tek armor, and covering 75% of the map in spam to 'defend their home server', the casual player is eradicated. It quickly becomes apparent that Ark official is not for mere mortals, but for the pure degenerates which can invest 12 hours a day playtime and know 5 people that are capable of the same. So why not move to official they say?

Unofficial:
Have commitments outside of video games? Tired of spending 3 hours taming a lvl 50 pteranadon which will die to a guy with a capped fabi and tek regardless? Tired of being unable to build anywhere as Ark Servers have not wiped since launch? Don't know 5 other degenerates willing to play ARK? Tired of non-moderated servers where cheaters have unsanctioned residency? Unofficial is for you! Here we offer a wide range of amenities, such as: 
1. Dead servers! Because nobody plays this fucking game, especially in OCE where there are approximately 40 players across 2 clusters which avoid sunlight as they thirst for the experience of wasting their hours on ARK.
2. The ability to play ARK casually! Just kidding! No person without degenerate friends and an obnoxious amount of free time can seriously compete against players who live and breath ark, spending days on end minmaxing their dino lines to wipe all the casual non-loser players off their already dead servers.
3. 5x rates means 5x easier??? Contrary to popular belief, '5x' written in unofficial server names does not actually represent 5x rates, it actually means that the tryhard ARK players which do not sleep have 5x more sh!t than you, and get 5x more loot from your trash base after soaking all your turrets with their 5x hp turtles.
4. At least you can build a base! I mean i guess, but then you are simply more ret@rded than the tryhard players which will wipe you anyway, and if any human does a cost-benefit analysis of building a base on unofficial, they will see an obvious trend where there is actually no benefit, and the cost scales with amount of playtime invested into a particular server, resulting in a net negative relationship, leading you to question, why play PVP at all?

PVE
Now you may be wondering, if there are no players on official and no players on unoffical, where does the concurrent ark playerbase come from? Crazy as it may sound, ARK is a scam, and the advertisement of ARK as an MMO PVP game is a blatant lie, as the wildcard marketing team gaslight people into believing that ARK is a PVP game with a substantial player base, but in reality, people are tired of the cyclical nature associated with getting raided and rebuilding on ark PVP servers. However, PVE servers may be the light at the end of the tunnel for ARK Survival Evolved, single-handedly carrying the ARK player count on steamcharts from 300 to ~40,000, but this only underscores the cancerous nature of attempting to play ark PVP, commonly resulting in PTSD, suicidal tendencies, and broken gaming peripherals. And if you are anything like myself, a casual gamer looking for an authentic and enjoyable PVP experience, your will arrive at the inevitable conclusion that this game is not worth playing.
 
TLDR: through a short summation of a few of ARK: Survival Evolved's issue, it would be preferrable for any human to commit suicide rather than spend >= 2 hours on this trash game.

Ark: Survival Evolved: A Game Beyond Comparison

In the world of gaming, where innovation and immersion reign supreme, one title stands tall above the rest: Ark: Survival Evolved. Developed by Studio Wildcard, this game represents the epitome of immersive, expansive, and enthralling game-play experiences. The sheer magnitude of its open-world environment, the depth of its mechanics, and the limitless possibilities it offers make Ark the undisputed champion in the gaming universe.

Firstly, Ark: Survival Evolved boasts an unparalleled level of immersion. Plunging players into a prehistoric world teeming with life and danger, it thrusts them into an environment that demands both survival skills and strategic thinking. From the majestic landscapes to the incredibly detailed creatures populating the world, every aspect of Ark has been meticulously designed to transport players into an alternate reality. The breathtaking visuals, coupled with the dynamic weather and day-night cycles, create an atmosphere so realistic that players can practically feel the sun's warmth or the chilling rain.

Moreover, the depth of gameplay mechanics in Ark is truly unparalleled. The game offers an extensive array of activities and tasks, ranging from basic survival necessities like hunting and gathering to more complex endeavors such as taming dinosaurs and constructing entire settlements. The crafting system allows players to create tools, weapons, and structures, fostering a sense of progression and accomplishment as they advance through the game. The variety of creatures to tame and ride adds another layer of excitement, making the game-play experience both diverse and exhilarating.

Furthermore, the multiplayer aspect of Ark elevates the gaming experience to new heights. The ability to form alliances, build communities, and engage in epic battles with other players or tribes adds an unpredictable and thrilling dimension to the game. The constant struggle for dominance and survival in a shared world fosters a sense of camaraderie and competition that keeps players engaged and invested in the game for hours on end.

Critics of Ark: Survival Evolved might argue that the game is challenging and time-consuming, citing the steep learning curve and the investment required to thrive in its world. However, it is precisely this challenge that makes Ark so rewarding. The sense of accomplishment derived from overcoming obstacles, taming powerful creatures, and building impressive structures is unparalleled in the gaming world.

In conclusion, Ark: Survival Evolved stands as a testament to the heights that gaming can reach. Its immersive world, intricate game-play mechanics, and the dynamic multiplayer environment combine to create an experience that transcends mere entertainment‚Äîit becomes a journey, a world to explore, conquer, and thrive in. As the gaming industry continues to evolve, Ark remains a shining example of what a truly exceptional game looks like, setting a standard that few can match.

Okay guys please listen.

I have started playing ARK: Survival Evolved in 2015.
Back then it was in Early Access and therefore the game didn't have nearly as much features as it does today. 
It only had one map and only the most iconic dinos were present at that time.
And at this stage I really loved the game. At first, I tested the game in a Free Weekend and I was so amazed that the following week I just couldn't get enough and bought it.
Even though the graphics were very demanding, the concept of the game was super catching.

I really loved the idea of dinosaurs dominating the world and that all you could do is to build a small safe space around you. Whenever you left that area, it was dangerous and took some actual decision-making.
The feeling of knocking down a Carnotaurus with only 20 tranq-arrows was amazing, considering how long it took to even make those. And the feeling of finally taming that powerful creature was astounding.
It was a time in my life where I would just sit in school and think about what I'll do next as soon as I come home.
It was a time where I was perfectly happy just because of my new little world that I could roam in. Similarly to what Minecraft was for many, including me.

Now here is a list of thing that I really loved and defined the game for me:
- Never being powerful. The fact that every journey could be your last. No matter when.
- The natural connection to your tamed dinosaurs
- The fitting primitive lifestyle with mere traces of modern society like automatic rifles or RIOT armor.
- The heavy grinding needed for simple structures. It took me a whole day to make a small wooden hut.
- The music. That music oh my god was it beautiful. Especially while Halloween or Christmas time.
- The various dinosaurs, that all were pretty fitting and only a few exceptions didn't "feel" like they shouldn't belong in the game.
- The tribes and alliances. The ability to actually have an enemy. The fear of being raided in the middle of the night. (Yes I really do not like the concept of offline protection).
- The thriving modding community that was present at that time.

But all of that got lost at some point. And I can really pinpoint that moment.
TEK Tier.

It's not really just the TEK Tier that is the problem, but a lot of reasons followed that made the game enjoyable for me.

To me the TEK Tier was way too op and it was clearly not directed to a PvE game, but it fueled the dominance war on official servers. Small tribes have absolutely no chance. Either you join, or you simply don't play on the server.

This really breaks the illusion of a dangerous world that you somehow ended up with with the only goal in mind being to survive.
It's gone! That humans can just come along with their laser beam Rex, fly the last 100 meters with their jetpacks and then insta-kill me with their sci-fi blaster is just too much.
This is not ARK nowadays. This is some random patchwork-game that spits on the grave of a dear memory of mine.

The fact that I can no longer enjoy nor recommend ARK is a sad true reality.

A great game, I love it! Hours of fun currently my most played steam game! It is an awesome game, I think most if not all survival players will enjoy this game it has a good challenge, but everything is modifiable in game making it super easy to make the game much more simple, countless hours in both single and online plat available. Some of the largest flaws and advantages of the game are the same depending on the player (such as how in PvP the game never stops so when you log off a player can still come to your base and take your loot requiring a pretty consistent play schedule. It is a sandbox but it does have end game bosses resulting in an end game goal each boss has has 3 different difficulties resulting in it being more accessible to all players, though if you want to have to follow quests and have certain objectives this is not the game for you. This game is also EXTREMELY grindy (with base modifiers) but this game is definitely in my top 3 games, though most of the dinos aren't accurate in the slightest, but most are rather unique in abilities, such as some have unique attacks or being good at harvesting materials that others aren't the leveling process. Overall I would give it a 9.5 out of 10 stars. This game also has an amazing steam workshop community that run wonderfully but be warned this game is big it takes a lot of room especially if you want expansions with it (which are worth getting if you have the space) this games pricing might as well not exist it is worth it to buy the game.

ü¶ï ARK: Survival Evolved - A Dinosaur-Fueled Epic Adventure ü¶ñ

ARK: Survival Evolved catapults players into a prehistoric playground, blending survival, exploration, and the thrill of taming dinosaurs into an epic adventure. While the journey can be both rewarding and challenging, it's an experience that stands out in the crowded survival game genre.

Graphics and Immersion (4.5/5):
Visually, ARK is a stunning testament to the power of modern gaming technology. The lush environments, diverse landscapes, and intricately designed creatures contribute to a truly immersive experience. The attention to detail, especially in the animation and behavior of dinosaurs, adds a layer of authenticity to the game world.

Survival Gameplay (4/5):
Survival is the name of the game in ARK, and it delivers a challenging yet engaging experience. Players must contend with hunger, thirst, and the elements while also facing the ever-present danger of hostile creatures. The depth of the crafting system and the need to build shelters and gather resources add a satisfying layer of complexity.

Dinosaur Taming and Riding (5/5):
The standout feature of ARK is undoubtedly the ability to tame and ride dinosaurs. The process of taming, which involves everything from feeding to protecting your future companion, is a rewarding and time-consuming endeavor. The thrill of riding a T-Rex into battle or soaring through the skies on a Pteranodon is an unparalleled joy in the gaming world.

Multiplayer Dynamics (4/5):
The multiplayer aspect of ARK introduces a dynamic social element. Forming tribes, engaging in PvP battles, and cooperating to tackle colossal creatures amplify the game's excitement. However, server performance and occasional technical hiccups can detract from an otherwise enjoyable multiplayer experience.

Exploration and Adventure (4.5/5):
The vast open world of ARK encourages exploration, and each biome holds its own challenges and unique creatures. Discovering hidden caves, encountering rare species, and unlocking the mysteries of the obelisks contribute to a sense of adventure that keeps players invested in the expansive world.

Learning Curve (3.5/5):
ARK's learning curve can be steep, especially for newcomers to the survival genre. While the game provides some guidance, understanding the intricacies of taming, crafting, and dealing with aggressive dinosaurs may take time. The community and online resources play a crucial role in easing the learning process.

Updates and Development (4/5):
The developers have shown a commitment to ARK's ongoing development, consistently delivering updates, expansions, and new features. The evolving nature of the game adds longevity and keeps players anticipating what's next in the ever-expanding ARK universe.

Conclusion (4/5):
ARK: Survival Evolved offers a captivating blend of survival mechanics, breathtaking visuals, and the sheer thrill of interacting with dinosaurs. While the learning curve might be steep, the depth of gameplay, the joy of taming, and the constant evolution of the game make it a compelling choice for fans of survival and adventure genres.

Ark has the base of a great game but it is so buggy that after 150hrs i just cant make anything last. from random save deletions to tames dissapearing, friends not being able to join my server. no matter how many youtube tutorials i watch they just cant be fixed. It is a game for addiction with lags, bugs, disconnections and rollbacks. It is been so when they released it and now when it is been bought by Chinese company (Snail Games)  it only goes down to be more worse, like for example adding more fantasy creatures than dinosaurs (still many dinosaurs missing). I even lost my first characters progress and to think about some good creatures i lost then i can not be very nice to say positive words. I do not know any other game with that many problems.Steam server info shows that 16 people are online, but when searching for someone or talking in the chat then nothing, and no ones nowhere. So steam is just showing those numbers to be up on  a list so that clients can see and prevent existing ones to go away?! Valguero is not that big not to find someone...and i know almost everybody!

I remember when i lost my first characters progress thanks to some strange lag that got replaced by some short rollback- like i died and lost my tribe and an ownership with it over my huge base and dinos. Thank god i pincoded some stuff (like dinos in pods) and doors to get trough. So it was on The island map!
Well, at least this one is a lot better than his predecessor ARK ASCENDED. Ascended just crashes all the time- even on good computers. So, basically, it is still better to stick to this one for sure.

So far so good.....PAY ATTENTION: know and understand that this game needs some boss specs to run! i'm using a sony vaio 8gig mem amd radeon etc.. laptop. i have to play on "low" settings. i'm ok with suffering graphics because of my min. specs. why? because this IS the best survival/crafting game in this genre..... i couldn't care less about the dinosaurs,yet because they are done so well,i'm loving them too.for an early access game,it feels "complete" already.

*if you do not have the ability to assign this game to your secondary graphics card(not the integrated one)...then put this game in your wishlist and wait for ark to be playable on potatoe pc's.(if that ever happens)*

In it's current state i HIGHLY recommend this game to anyone who enjoys survival/crafting games.it's top dog as far as i'm concerned.

Ok.
This was a good game however the storage for this game is unacceptable
440 ish GB. Almost half a Terabyte for 1 GAME.
If you have a Nasa computer with Nasa storage and Nasa download speed then get this game.
But other than that just don't bother with this game.
Also snail games (the parent company of Wildcard studios) are the worst pieces of shit I have ever seen on this planet.
Here is a video that explains the Snail games issue: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p30ErFvU0-0
Anyway moral of the review:
Bad parent company
Terrible optimisation for storage
Also costs a bit too much
Please only buy if you can install the game and if you have the money to buy it.
